description:
Have been here twice now and absolutely love this place. It has been consistently wonderful with service and food. The servers are so kind and attentive. The DJ they have had playing is great and definitely adds to the ambience. Just wish the music continued beyond 9:30. 

The steak tartare is the best I've had so far in ththe Bay Area and I have tried this at over a dozen different nearby restaurants. 

Cafe Prague does an amazing job with the more traditional Central European dishes. Svickova is a hard dish to get right  and theirs is delicious. The goulash with sauerkraut is also made to perfection. The portions are extremely generous and we always have leftovers. 

Looking forward to my return visits to this delightful restaurant.
author: Mary W.

description:
The food is ok, although quality and portion size is definitely down from when they were on Pacific.  Our waitress yesterday was not polite and argumentative and I saw her making faces after speaking to another table. I've been a customer for years but her attitude is really off putting and the food is not worth the annoyance.  

Also in this day of square etc who doesn't accept a credit card or who makes not having a working landline an excuse? Shady.
author: Mia G.

description: Have been here a number of times and really like the authentic food, service and location. Reminds me of an out-of-the-way cafe in the altstadt district of some small historic town in Europe.
author: Greg H.

description:
It's 21st century and there is this place in the middle of Financial District in San Francisco that still does not accept credit cards. No, that's not a beginning of a mediocre science fiction story. It's reality. And this place is called "Cafe Prague".

Although aspiring to be a go to place for Czech beer and Central European cuisine, the choice of both drinks and food is really limited. On the upside, the place is cozy, well, at least inside. The outside is a grim back alley full of garbage containers. Surprisingly enough, they don't bother and there is an option to sit outdoors.
author: Jakub S.

description: I went to this cafe during my lunch break. The location of the restaurant is an alleyway, the area is a bit sketch. I saw a person shoot himself with something, I'm not going to pass judgment on what it was. The restaurant itself was super dark and kind of spooky, maybe they're playing it up for halloween ? Anyways on to the actual food, I ordered the tuna melt which cane with tomato soup. I have never been a fan of tomato soup, so maybe my prior prejudices may come in to place when I say it's was horrible. I have had tomato soup in the past but this one, I especially hated. As for the tuna melt, I like a good tuna melt sandwich. They decided to put their own spin on this sandwich. It had avacadoes, tomatoes, dijon mustard, and some other sauce that made it taste sour. I honestly can say this was the worst tuna melt that I have had. The dijon mustard just killed it for me. I will stay away from both items in general. They killed my craving for a tuna melt . I'm know I'm being a bit harsh, but I'm trying to be as honest as possible without being hurtful.
author: Maria N.

description:
BAD!!!
Walked in with couple of friends to the bar for drinks and literally the lady behind the bars says: yes?... I mean seriously!! At the minimum say hey guys or good evening or what's up!
We ask for drinks and we give a credit card, she rudely says: only cash we don't take card.. I mean seriously!! In San Francisco in the heart of the financial district and don't take credit card with attitude!!
Had my drink and wanted to use the washroom, while heading there she shouted EXCUSME ME!! I said I need to use the rest room, she said OK! It seems like you need a permission to use it.

First and last time.
author: A N.

description: Came here for Eurocircle Oktoberfest event. There was a happy hour menu. I had the bratwurst and strudel($6). It was nice. However, the bratwurst was small and overpriced($9). Strudel was good and no complaints. Tried some of my friend's beer. The water came in a mason jar(cool). Mark was spinning some unique music. The service is nice. Fun place.
author: Denise C.

description:
Great place for a cheap beer. They have Happy Hour that include .5L beers for 6.50. Cheap price and I really enjoyed the taste of the Czech beer! It was tasty! 

They've got both indoor and outdoor seating tucked away on a small alley. The outdoor seating is really nice on a cool San Francisco day. As we were leaving around 6:30pm, there was a dj playing music inside. Not sure what the vibe might turn into at night but seemed fun. 

Overall, great place to grab a beer for a good price!
author: Courtney O.

description: Excellent food in a cool atmosphere. Hidden in an alley across from my work and transamerica and next to the comedy club the whole environment is great. I ordered goulash and selected the dumplings with it and the bacon split pea soup. The meat was perfectly marinated and a great combo with the dumplings. The split pea soup was tasty and I especially liked the croutons they used. Check this place out.
author: Sean G.

description:
3 stars because the beer and ambience were good. Only place in the city where I got a 1L, giant mug full of Spaten beer. We arrived, sat down and were handed menus. We ordered 3 large beers, a steak/bread plate and a cheese plate. This place is a little fancy (or tries to be) therefore you end up paying a pretty penny for food options. Everything (except the beer) comes in smaller portions. These aren't meant to be meals. They're meant to be snacks while you sip your beer or wine.

There are two waitresses here. Nice waitress and mean waitress. We got both. We simply asked one of the waitresses if there was a price for more bread and she snapped at us saying, "More bread? You want more bread?!" She grabbed our plate and headed to the kitchen. We were confused. Was it rude that we asked her if bread was free? This wasn't an Olive Garden where there's an unspoken rule about free bread. Cafe Prague isn't known for free bread so we didn't know. She returned with our bread. We finished our drinks and got our check. If you can handle a little rudeness and don't mind small, expensive food with your beer, this is the place for you.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Just happened upon this place after not feeling like grabbing a bite and a drink at The Royal Exchange because it was so crowded and I was alone.
What a cute spot! Charming location and friendly service. Nice happy hour menu. I had the tuna crostini which was plenty for a light dinner ($10) and a decent $8 glass of Mondavi Chardonnay. Will for sure come back and try again. I have a feeling if I worked in the area I'd be a regular.
author: Teresa S.

description: Where to begin.  The owner reminded me of baby Huey.  The waitress was rude and unhappy to be at her job, she made that very clear in her body language.  We were there during downtown with maybe 2 other customers but still managed to wait nearly an hour for our food to arrive.  I was not impressed with the food but my girlfriend who is Czech was embarrassed to have brought me here to experience Czech food. On the bright side, the beer was good.
author: Cookie M.

description: Very cool place! A hidden gem! Great food, big drinks and cute decor. The waitress was super friendly and helpful. Would definitely recommend and can't wait to go back next time I'm in SF again.
author: Barbara B.

description: Small place. Tucked away is an alley behind a fire station. A nice relaxing place to escape the office. Black bean soup is delicious.
author: H R.

description: Stopped in for lunch - ordered the chicken sandwich to go and it came with a super fresh salad. I paid using a card, perhaps this is a recent change. Czechvar on tap, I plan to return for one of those and try more on the menu.
author: Eric G.

description:
The short: thankful that Cafe Prague is my first introduction to Czech food

I haven't had Czech food before, so I was more than excited to check out this place with a friend who recommended it.

I arrived first, and the waitress let me sit down before my friend arrived. Thanks! 

It turns out my friend has only had their sandwiches (American style) here, which she loves. I ended up ordering the goulash paprika and tomato soup (soup or greens are complimentary). 

The tomato soup was very delicious, holding a solid level of flavors and a thick consistency. When the goulash arrived, I thought it was kind of small, but then I realized that I was fast approaching my satiety level as soon as I took some bites of the goulash. Each bite of the beef was very soft and tender, topped with savory sauce with a slight kick. And the soft, yet dense bread was like a sponge, absorbing all the wonderful flavors of the sauce. Since I was so full half-way through, I took the rest of the goulash home. The leftovers still tasted just as good the next day!

My friend and I caught up for almost an hour, and the waitress never intruded, letting us hold our conversation. 

I also loved the decor in here. It was very spacious, and cozy, and had that feeling of this-is-what-I-might-see-in-Prague-when-I-visit, which is a huge contrast to the minimalist, hipster, vibe I get from other parts of SF.

Can't wait to come back so I can escape from the high-rise and tech life of Fidi!

Sidenote: cash only; there is an ATM on site to withdraw if necessary
author: Catherine W.

description: Quite reasonable foods and good services.  But really?  Cash only in San Francisco?  That's just not heard of.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description: Cafe Prague is a nice little European cafe on Merchant St near Union square in San Francisco. It is sort of in a backhole alley, but the interior is quite quaint. The servers and manager are very friendly and you can sit on some sofas to have some drinks or to have dinner. We came here in the early evening and there was barely a wait. The best thing, hands down, on the menu was the goulash- the paprika and spice mixture is perfect -- perfection! The mixture of the meat in the stew is a very even texture. I could also taste a little bit of fine beer with the sauce, albeit slight. This is such a unique Czech/Hungarian flavor that I would definitely recommend coming here multiple times to try the varied things on the menu. The cheese plate is also quite on point, and the whole dinner only cost each person around 15-25 dollars, when everything is split.
author: Han S.

description: Don't go here if you want good service. The people are flat out rude. We didn't even bother ordering food, they ruined it for us before we even had the chance to put our order in!
author: Nikha M.

description: Wonderful place. Had the steak tartar (incredibly reasonable price for happy hour and delicious!) and the Spinach salad (large, good, but not great).  Service was fabulous.  I would definitely go back.  A real gem tucked out of the way.
author: Nancy C.

description: Amazing comfort food, nice staff, cool atmosphere. Never had a bad dish. I recommend the beef sauerbraten
author: Micah H.

description: Today, I went to Cafe Prague for the first time in at least a decade, and I was happy to learn that it is every bit as good as ever, with an even better, cozier atmosphere and more menu items. I ate what I always used to eat: grilled ham and provolone on foccacia. It tasted exactly as incredible as I remembered. I'm not sure what makes it better than any other ham and cheese, but I'm pretty sure it's the bread, which is grilled to a perfect crunch. The ham and cheese ratio is also perfect, so maybe it's just everything. The sandwich also came with a cup of soup; I chose the lentil soup, and it was hearty, warm, and delicious. The service was very, very fast and very friendly. Probably my favorite sandwich joint in the city, and I'm eager to try that goulash paprika next. Cash only!
author: AJ P.

description: I enjoyed the energy overall, it made me want to be back in EU. The lighting and art on the walls were great. And not too loud for noise. I enjoyed their tuna crostini with olives and their pork sausage was delightful. However, fair warning to avoid the steak tartar. It was heavy with ketchup. (Yes, I said ketchup).
author: Melissa F.

description:
Update: The norovirus infection we got after having lunch here on 11/10 was very highly contagious. I managed to infect 3 other people, two of whom are immunosuppressed: a 78 year-old in cancer remission, and the other, a pyelonephritis patient already battling a particularly antibiotic-resistant kidney infection. I don't know where you order your produce and meats, how you prepare your food, or if your servers are aware of the proper restaurant safety and hygiene practices, but you OUGHT to be ashamed of yourselves. 

----

My friends and I had lunch here on Thursday, Nov 10. By Friday night, we were all exhibiting symptoms of norovirus infection. Unfortunately for me, I spent the weekend with people with very weakened immune systems (just prior to realizing I caught the stomach flu). If either of them gets infected, I'm going to be very pissed.
author: Aileen C.

description: Outstanding cuisine! I enjoyed the sun-dried tomato, Brie, and chicken sandwich. Definitely a must when I come to the city.
author: Michelle Ashlee P.

description:
Had a great lunch, Chicken sandwich was very tasty and my friend had Niçoise salad which also was very authentic.
I also had incredible tomato soup with gnocchi.
The best ever taste. I heard it's their signature soup. Have to be back for their happy hour.
I want to try their selection of beers. Their staff is very friendly. Overall amazing place to go. Looking forward to go back there again!
author: Anastasia V.

description:
My friend and I stopped by Prague since we had a late meetup at Hidden Vine next door. Since Hidden Vine may not have a full menu, Prague seemed reasonable in terms of pricing and the interior seems kind of quirky and comfortable with bench seating and cushions against the walls.  

After sitting down and order a couple of items for dinner, the oddest sounds entered my ears.  The music that played in the background was a mix of my 2013 Pop playlist and my Daddy Yankee Reggaeton playlists on Spotify.  Needless to say, I was digging the music although it was a bit loud.

In terms of food, I really liked their burrata although the vinegar dressing on the greens was a bit heavy handed.  The other items, the tuna crostinis and the tomato soup, were disappointing.  I think the soup was supposed to have gnocchi in there but when it got to us, it turned out to be bread pieces.  Ummm looks like gnocchi isn't the same as gnocchi.  The soup itself was good as it was a creamy tomato soup but I was bummed about the swap.  The tuna was a bummer due to the tuna being canned and not fresh.  I should've known better to order tuna from a place that may not look like that they use real fish for their dishes.

Of course, also found out that they are cash only at the end of the night.  Usually they should have signage of some sort to warn customers that they don't take credit cards.  Well whatever they are doing to convey that message, it wasn't good enough.  It was a good thing that I had cash on me or else I would've had to use whatever ATM that they had on site.

Overall, it was a below average experience here that could have been better if they communicated their CASH ONLY preference and delivered the food quicker(they took more than 30 minutes to deliver soup, burrata, and tuna fish on bread).  I can't and likely won't recommend a place like this to anyone I know.
author: Ben H L.

description: Waitress is beautiful Petra, but has bad table side manner and is very rude. Was very hungry and wanted to order food, but the waitress was very mean and seemed like she didn't want my business so I took it elsewhere. I just moved to a couple blocks down from this place and will avoid and tell my coworkers to avoid as well. Luckily beer is beer. I will not be going back because of the bad attitudes.
author: Manuel T.

description: Discovered this gem when I ordered a Meal Pal lunch (food pickup) during the weekday. Went back for dinner one night. It's such a cozy spot to go for a drink after work. It's hidden in an alley and has some outdoor seating and a lot of seating inside. The service was quick and friendly. The sandwiches were great. The takeout food I ordered was really good too. Would definitely come here again!
author: Nicole D.

description: Wow can't believe it. This place sucks ! And the most racist place ever. This white girl who may be the manager or owner  wanted the table we were sitting to be empty for no reason. She wanted to take our drink and stand ?
author: Rajib B.

description:
Cafe Prague is hidden on a side street in the financial district and I had a little trouble finding it, especially with San Francisco's notoriously spotty GPS (no Google Maps, I'm not walking on the Bay Bridge). However, once you're inside you're transported far away from techie SF to a cozy, Czech cafe. At Cafe Prague, you'll find a well-priced lunch menu of tasty sandwiches, soups, and salads, and great Czech and German beers on tap. SF had put a big dent in my wallet up until Cafe Prague, but I felt like my money at Cafe Prague was well spent, and my stomach left very happy.

I settled on a prosciutto di palma sandwich served alongside mixed greens. I combined this with a bowl of french lentil soup. Everything was great, especially the sandwich on toasted baguette. I practically licked the bowl of french lentil (yellow in color) clean and with a nice dark beer, the bill came up to about $20.00. Cafe Prague has just become my favorite spot for a sit-down lunch in downtown San Francisco. Get a table along the wall with colorful murals and large pillows strewn about. 

Cash only.
author: Richard H.

description:
Part of my genuine "like" for this place is rooted in 2 observations
1. It is rare to find Czech food almost anywhere outside of Prague / Czech Republic unless you are lucky to live in a town with a lot of Czech emigrants.

2. The place is open late - the kitchen closed around 10:30 pm on a Fri night - and even though they had run out of dumplings they still served up a dish by substituting mash potatoes. The area is pretty dry for dinner after 6pm even though there are movie theatres, comedy club, and heck SF is a big city...


We came in without a reservation while they were filled with a private party  - it is a small place. But they apologized and offered us a table outside - now that is what we remembered from Prague - a lot of cafes with outside streetside seating - and we did not have to hear the music which is loud.

We shared ( and no fuss over sharing ... )

Greek Salad,
Goulash Paprika  ( there are two kinds of Goulash - this one is more Hungarian )
Green Pea Soup with Ham
Apple Strudel


we each had half liters of Czech beer, one Pilsner Urquel, and one Czechvar - which I had not tasted before.

Enjoyed the food. Hope to return to try some other food. When I walked back to use the bathroom the place seemed very clean. We were very full so took the Strudel to go.


They do not take creditcards but they had a working ATM, that caught us by surprise.
author: ce c.

description:
Went here for lunch one day. Really enjoyed it! HIT THE SPOT so to speak.

- Quick service
- A lot of menu options

We got the Pesto Chicken Sandwich and Tuna Melt. Both tasty. (Each came with soup or salad, had one of each, both good.)
author: Rachel T.

description:
My boyfriend and I ate here for a quick dinner before a comedy show. We ordered the Italian meatballs, the Polish sausage, a Caesar salad and a Greek salad.

When the Italian sausage arrived, we were really surprised that they weren't anything special. The Polish sausage was also not something to be excited about here

Then our salads came, his Caesar tasted like a lemon salad and as easy as a Caesar  is to make, they managed to make this one almost inedible. 

My Greek salad didn't have lettuce. I suppose that wouldn't have been so bad had the only three ingredients not been cucumbers, tomatoes, onions. It's only saving grace? It also had olives. 

The service here was mediocre at best and downright terrible for the fact that there were only two other couples and one man at the bar. 

The icing on the cake was that they only accept cash, which was fine with us except for the fact that my boyfriend left additional cash in order to get a little bit of change. She ended up bringing back too much change and then never coming back. He of course left the extra money she gave us back, as well as a tip. We finally had to go, so we didn't miss our comedy show.
author: Kaylee A.

description:
Love this little flavor of Prague in the middle of Financial District in SF. 

Spaten Optimator FTW.
author: Sahil B.

description:
I came here because Hidden Vine was busy. All I wanted was a glass of wine during Happy Hour, but I should have known it would be super busy. In retrospect, I was better off standing in the back of Hidden Vine and standing while sipping wine... but my friend suggested walking next door to Cafe Prague because it was less busy.

Actually, it was pretty empty, so that was nice. Plus they have Happy Hour from 4pm to 7pm. Glasses of wine are around $6 but they only serve Robert Mondavi wine so $6 sounds about right. Not to diss or anything. The waitresses served us this pizza bread looking thing but was not great but a nice gesture. The service in general was not good. The waitresses/bartenders only spoke to each other but in a foreign language. They did not directly interact with us and were not attentive at all for how few people were in the cafe. The food menu sounded kinda tasty, but otherwise I'm not motivated to come back here again. This just makes me more determined to get a spot at Hidden Vine and have a better backup plan.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Those from Eastern Europe will understand the concept and might give this place a higher rating. Cafe Prague presents to its patrons a Europe - like relaxed atmosphere...The Cafe will make a lot of European folks make feel like home. It is located on a narrow and somewhat quiet alley...There are some tables outside... It has a great selection of Czech beers on draft ranging from Staropromen to Pilsner Uruquell. The servers are from Czech republic (at least the ones I've seen) and very nice and hospitable. 
HOWEVER; ! For those folks who are spoiled by SF's dining options and have never been to Europe this place simply  wont work... For instance, when you are ordering a steak tartar, you are expecting a meat dish made from finely chopped or minced raw beef... Raw is a key word in the above statement. At Café Prague, you get a medium rare ground beef instead. After trying this appetizer, we decided to finish our beers and go have some food somewhere else. To top it off, it's a cash only place... Really? Cash only place in SF?-At a place  where patrons expect the venues to have credit cards, paypal, venmo payment options and God only knows what else they expect (Bitcoins?!!!!)....
Based on the above factors - I will give this cafe 3 stars (....
P.S. I will be back for their beers for sure...
author: George B.

description:
I really wanted to like this place . Was in Prague( the city) a few years back. Loved the food there- and thought this cafe would bring back good memories. It did not . Substandard food, lousy service. Deafening weird music. Waitress seemed to be interested in hanging out with her buddies and not serving the customers. Even water glass was not refilled promptly- and when it was - it was  lukewarm tap water . I read other reviews- just hoping this experience will not end up in food poisoning or worse. But I was pretty upset so I'm writing about this immediately upon arriving home. Oh and the kicker: I really had to laugh about this one: when her highness finally sauntered to our table to deliver the check- she put it in front of me instead of my male companion . That's just in poor taste. 
One positive note: the decor is kind of nice and cozy . But I am having a splitting headache now from suffering through their musical choices. Sadly, i WILL NOT be back
author: rinna s.

description:
I lived in Europe for a bit and I can agree that the atmosphere and look & feel of the restaurant/cafe is very much like a casual cafe in a homey part of town.

They have a Happy Hour menu (4-7pm weekdays). A good sized beer starts at $6.50. Not bad.

But here's the negatives:
-Waitress did a poor job of managing the tables and the tabs are open. 
-It is CASH ONLY. There's an ATM...
-The appetizers are subpar at best.
-Location is pretty terrible, the bar is in an alley and there are trashcans right next to it. The entrances are open blocked by cars/trucks in the alley.
-There's outdoor seating but when I walked into the bar/around the outdoor seating there were flies... gross.
author: Amy H.

description:
STAROPRAMEN
Good light beer. On draft. 

STEAK TARTAR WITH GARLIC TOAST
This is really good. Both the tartare and the garlic toast had a spicy kick to it, which made my day. The meat was tender and delicious, and it paired perfectly with the toast. 

NY STEAK SANDWICH
The steak meat was cut into small slices and put between a good French roll. My friend really enjoyed this dish, but I prefer the tartare to the sandwich for a lighter meal.. 

LENTIL SOUP
I was thinking i ordered the green lentil soup, but mistakenly ordered the regular lentil soup. It's very hearty and I got the bowl to share with my friend. I didn't think it was going to come out in a humongous pho bowl though. We could have shared that bowl of soup with 4 people! Nonethelss, it was very good, but it needed more salt and pepper to taste.

ATMOSPHERE 
Super cute cafe / restaurant with lots of cushioned sofas and chairs. It's one of the few like this in San Francisco and I'm happy that it was right behind my hotel in the alley. I'll be back here next time I'm in SF!
author: Debby L.

description:
Czech beer in liter mugs
Attentive staff
Good food
Nice happy hour
Friendly crowd
Outdoor tables during nice weather
Warm, European styled interior
Interesting music
Sports on 2 TVs
author: J E.

description:
This place is delightful, and the service was European (kinda surly, kinda slow) but it contributes to the relaxed atmosphere. They also didn't try to chase me away from table even after I lingered for 45 minutes after paying the bill, so I think that relaxed atmosphere is a good and bad thing. 

The wine that I had was a delightfully dry white, and the "glass" they gave us had a VERY strong pour; quite a nice value for $8. I'd absolutely go back.
author: Aaron Y.

description:
Pros: Warm atmosphere, friendly staff, authentic flavors, great beers.

Cons: My lentil soup was watery and my pork loin was tough, cash only (ATM on premises).
author: Jim Y.

description:
Upgrading Cafe Prague because my favorite after-work Czech happy hour spot is also a decent lunch spot too. 

But first a quick update on happy hour. Yes from 4-7pm, there are specials on mulled spiced wines and Czech brewskis but you should also get an order of meatballs! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cafe-prague-san-francisco-2?select=c8O0IM4Fm8vgqIe1X3Amuw#c8O0IM4Fm8vgqIe1X3Amuw) Yum! They go together perfectly for happy hour. 

While Cafe Prague has typically been a post-work spot for me, I've come to enjoy if for lunch too since coming here with a colleague for lunch. I love the smoked salmon sandwich on whole wheat toast with a side of tomato soup. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cafe-prague-san-francisco-2?select=c8O0IM4Fm8vgqIe1X3Amuw#K2bK_6e-z18cxw7gnvO2rg) The creamy tomato soup with gnocchi is pure comfort food on a chilly SF afternoon and I just love a smoked salmon sandwich with cream cheese, capers, and red onion. Spinach soup here is also a good bet. 

Lunch. Just another reason why I love my little hidden Czechoslovakian gem of a cafe/bar. But don't forget about happy hour too! Cafe Prague is a cozy spot for drink, food, and conversation.
author: Jon L.

description: Came here last night after Hidden Vine next door was packed. While I appreciated the heavy pours of wine (didn't order any food since I had read other reviews), this place was SO SMOKEY that I had to shower immediately upon returning home, and everything I wore yesterday smells like I lived inside of an actual barbecue. If they are going to cook whatever they were cooking, they need to work on their ventilation, or at least open the door to create some air flow. Would not return.
author: Nora S.

description:
This is one of my favorite hidden gems in San Fran.  I have been here several times and am definitely coming back for more. 
Yummy Czech food, great beer and awesome atmosphere!!
author: Mary W.

description: This time (about 2 1/2 yrs after my last visit) I went for lunch. Waitress was attentive, food was good. I think I'll start visiting more often again, since they are the only place around who makes Segedin goulash. Parking on a street its still problem....
author: Johnny J.

description: I really liked having a cold, 1 liter Czech lager in a tall, cold glass. I had the Staropramon beer and enjoyed it. It was a light lager on tap from the Czech Republic. 1 Liter was $10. I sat at the bar, and the bartender changed the tv to the local Giants game on a slower Monday evening. For dinner I ordered the roast pork loin with red cabbage and dumplings. It was delicious. It included two full grilled and marinated pork chops.  I stuffed myself and ate the whole plate. It cost $18. Most meals were in that range. Soup and salads and sandwiches were also on the menu. The bar had beer and wine but not liquor.  I will definitely come back again.
author: Eric W.

description:
I've always really wanted to like this place.  It's cute.  It's out of the way.  It's comfortable.  It's seemingly authentic.  I can imagine myself in there on a rainy SF day with a beer and a game on tv.  

But I just can't.  I've come to Cafe Prague at the very least, six or seven times.  At a range of times - lunch, happy hour, and dinner.  I've tried many different things.  Goulash, sandwiches, soups, salads, beef quesadillas.  

Maybe I just don't like Czech food?  I don't know.  The best thing I've had here was the steak sandwich.  But it's not notable to me in any way.  

I always get the Straropamen and I do love that beer.  Everything else is kinda disappointing.

Not to mention their service is INCREDIBLY slow.  So much so that you're guaranteed to just sit there waiting half the time - for a menu, for your food, for your bill, for your change.

Why do I keep going back?  The bf loves it for some odd reason.  The things you do for love.  I just order a salad now and suck it up as a healthy lunch.
author: Ghizal A.

description:
CASH ONLY.

Good, unique food. But be forewarned that a dinner for two costs about $70 total, and you'll need to pay cash for that.  They have an ATM, but who even brings a debit card around with them anymore?
author: Scott P.

description: I stopped in for a beer and a snack. We had the cheese plate and a Staropramen on draft. Staropramen is a Czech Pilsner and is delicious. My first time having it. The cheese plate was very good as well.I thought the beer prices were good and it wasn't even happy hour. The bar tender was very nice.
author: David F.

description:
So it's my last night on a 4-day visit to SF, and I found myself without dinner plans, so I decided to take the advice of a new friend I met on the flight here: "Cafe Prague. Get the steak sandwich and a beer. Go in the evening for outside seating."

I made the walk from my hotel, and found a very charming restaurant tucked in a side street near the fire station.  I took his advice, and ordered the steak sandwich and a Pilsner from the friendly waitress. 

The food was not a disappointment. The beer comes at a half liter for 6 bucks, and it was..well, it was good beer. I'm no beer aficionado, but I liked it.

I found out later, before the sandwich came, that I had a choice of soup or salad, so I opted for the French Lentil soup. Why not, be adventurous, right? The soup came out nice and hot, and it was thick with pieces of carrots and vegetables. I enjoyed it quite a bit. It was very hearty, and all I could think of as I ate it was that a great deal of work and time had gone into making it. 

The steak sandwich was quite delicious as well. It's served on a very crisp, crunchy baguette, which has a nice soft inside. The steak had a little pink too it, which is perfect, and the sandwich came with greens (maybe spinach... maybe lettuce), tomato, and just the right amount of bleu cheese. I don't really like bleu cheese, but I let it happen, and the combination of flavors was quite delicious. I could be wrong, but I believe there was another kind of cheese on the sandwich as well, and it had kind of a Brie melt. It may have been havarti though. Either way, it added to the overall profile nicely. 

See the pics for more detail. This is a great place in the city yet it still retains a neighborhood, European feel. As an added plus, it was open until 11, which was a nice convenience for me.
author: Peter S.

description: Love the ambiance here.  They have a few czech beers on tap, and the beers can come in large sizes.  The staff are friendly, and you'll get some free snacks if you're there during happy hour.
author: Herb G.

description:
So legit
    I had a nice red wine and delicious goulash.  Super comfy couch seating and a nice waitstaff. Oh i also had a really good split pea soup with bacon!
author: Scott D.

description:
I have been to this place a few times and it is ok. Just ok. Come here for the selection of European beer on tap, not the food.

Service takes forever....seriously forever. So bring people you like and who you want to sit with and talk to for a long time because you will be waiting forever to get your bill.
author: Gina G.

description:
This is such a great lunch spot! They have a great selection of traditional items, like beer goulash (which I highly recommend) and regular lunch items, like sandwiches and salads. They also have a great beer selection, although I can never partake at lunch time. 

I love their traditional items, and their dumplings are fantastic. I also really like how their sandwiches come with soup or salad, it really makes you feel like you are getting your money's worth. I have tried multiple sandwiches there and I am never disappointed. I also like their outdoor space, although with all of the construction happening in that alley, it's not really a pleasant experience. The ambiance inside the restaurant is great though, so either way, you'll have a good time.
author: Regina L.

description: While desperately looking for something to eat at close to 11:00 in the Financial District last night, we stumbled across Cafe Prague. We were informed that the kitchen was closed, but they would still cook up some appetizers for us! Wonderful and tasty, and so cool of them to do that. We will be back ; )
author: Stefan S.

description:
Steak tartare is an appetizer but it can be a meal of its own. I love the subtle spiciness the garlic toast has. This is a tapenade protein style. 

New York steak sandwich on a French baguette 
has tender meat, a hint of blue cheese and the condiments of a burger. Awesome combination. 

Lentils soup with carrot and cilantro is a good addition to the steak.

They have outdoors seating street style and cash only. I love it.
author: Amine M.

description:
I really enjoy this place. It brings me back to Prague! 

The beer, food and prices are great and I like that they have different types of seating. 

It's a great spot to bring a group of friends and enjoy some liter beers.

Heads up that they get busy fast on Fridays so get their early if you want a table.
author: Sabrina J.

description:
Updated on 7/28/2013 and downgraded to ONE star instead of two. Yes, I'm still extremely upset about the experience to date from my previous post in April.

----I just learned that one of my friends actually put out $50 MORE THAN his fair share to pay for the dinner because my party was in such a rush that we didn't have time to get everyone to dish out more money. Cafe Prague should've never messed up on this dinner and should've had more attentive service given that we were seated late and my party received our food almost an HOUR later than expected with a reservation.

I'm furious and would give this restaurant zero stars if Yelp would let me.

-----

***Lost my reservation for a party of 20, NEVER again for a large party or any eating occasion.

It was my birthday and I made a 7:15pm reservation for a party of 20 earlier this week for a Friday dinner. Everything was good to go and the cafe called me back several times to confirm a couple of details. I was even told that I would get the couch area to ensure we had more than enough seats for everyone.

When we arrived at the restaurant, I learned that my reservation had not been communicated and there was not a table in sight to be reserved for my party. For a reservation of two people, maybe I can understand that a reservation would get lost, but not for 20 people. My party was finally seated around ~7:45pm, my friends were starving and we received our food an hour later. With plans to meet up with others at 9:30pm, our dinner was a bit rushed and my party ended up splitting to meet others while I stayed back to wrap up the check -- Yes, that's a pretty expensive check to have people leaving while I'm still wrapping up the cash. We had to ask for the check twice before it came to our table. No comps in dinner, no sympathy for the party for lacking in customer service.

What I'm most sad about is that I've recommended several people to find this restaurant, but that won't be happening anymore.
author: Christina L.

description: Authentic as the wait staff are Czech but whomever is doing the cooking knows what they're doing as the Goulash and peas soup are wonderful, beer delicious and staff efficient and friendly. I'd definitely would go back.
author: N A.

description: I really enjoyed the Caesar Salad and the Caprese Salad (especially Caprese!). Beautifully plated and great tasting. I loved being able to sit outside as well. The staff were very friendly and helpful. However, being cash only was a bummer. There is an ATM inside.
author: Lacey R.

description: A truly special place. The Czech food is great, as is the beer. At the top of my restaurant list in all of SF.
author: Michael B.

description: Cute environment. Food was delicious. Server came up to us frequently. Maybe a little too frequently. I asked the server if the soup had bacon in it and she said no, but there was clearly bacon in it when I dug into it. Being cash only is also inconvenient.
author: Ashneel K.

description: Overall love the food! A little on the Oily side though. Their soup is yummy and fresh tasting. Don't forget to try their classic menu!
author: Yilun W.

description:
I should have paid closer attention to the reviews.... the services does not suck, it stinks.... I had to beg to have my bill brought to me so I could pay and get up out of this place... drink order was wrong, they brought out the appetizer and entree at the same time and not once did the server stop and ask if I wanted something to drink.

While the food was good, run quickly away from this place and go elsewhere....
author: Keith K.

description: Was not impressed with this place..ordered a drink and THEN was told they didn't take cards, only cash . Would have been nice to be told that first. Also the blonde waitress was more interested in her phone, won't be back.
author: Patricia B.

description:
Wow I don't even know where to start. 
Maybe it was a bad night for them. 
There were only 2 people working on a Saturday night and it was a disaster. 
It got so bad I thought I was on Candid Camera. It honestly became funny at times. 
I'm not gonna even go on further here. 
Just a bad experience.  However it's one we'll laugh about later.
author: Mike B.

description:
If you've been to Europe, Cafe Prague can take you back there. If you've been to Prague, even more so. Cafe Prague reminds me of a fine dining restaurant in Prague back in 1990 when you could buy a 5 course dinner for $2, except a bit run down. In spite of the chair-damaged walls and stained carpeting, the atmosphere is cozy and comfortable with deep banquette seating on one wall, a table-height counter on the opposite wall, and a cool bar, arranged perfectly for meeting the neighborhood, or the after work crowd. There's a lot to look at and 2 TVs if you're alone or want to see your team in action. In a way, maybe depending on the music, it's like Copenhagen.

I love this place, because it's got a neighborhood feel in the midst of the financial district, the food is good, the beer excellent (try the Staropramen), has great wine, comfortable seating, and there's free wifi! (just ask for the password.) The carpeting and exposed beams in the ceiling help keep the noise level down.

Mondays are especially nice to come in and bring a laptop or a book since it's quiet. But Tuesdays and the rest of the week, lunchtime gets crowded. 

There's also outdoor seating on quiet little Merchant Street tucked between Clay and Washington halfway between Battery and Sansome.

The lunchtime waitress remembers people. She has helped make Cafe Prague my go-to spot when I want to get out of the house or meet a friend downtown for lunch.

The music during lunch might be European classical, but at 4pm, the tempo changes, ready for happy hour.
author: Kiai K.

description:
DINERS: PLEASE READ THE ONE STAR REVIEWS---

Unbelievable experience on 7/15: VERY special night out, reservation for 2 made days before over the phone as suggested by their website...upon arrival we have no reservation with the following explanation: "My manager didn't tell me you had a reservation; I've been gone for three days".

What the ....??

And...if you can take the time to read the 1 star reviews you will see this is a strategy they have used before, even with a group of 20 that had reservations!!

Why can't Yelp have "Zero" stars?

Obviously we will never go back & will NEVER recommend it to anyone else, especially our eastern European friends & family...

To be fair I have written a personal note to the restaurant itself but am not expecting anything...
author: Michael P.

description: This restaurant is a hidden gem. The food is good, atmosphere is comfortable, and the servers incredibly nice. Great value!
author: Linda P.

description:
Walking in really does feel like going to another country.  I was surprised that the restaurant accepts only cash given how insanely expensive everything on the menu is.  Given that I didn't have $60 in cash, I opted to just get a beer and relax for bit.  The beer selection was good and $7 got me a HUGE stein!

I really liked the feel of the place and had a great time hanging out chatting with people while drinking my new favorite beer.
author: Barrett B.

description: They only take cash, so that's a bummer. Luckily I had cash on me, but my buddy didn't, so I paid for him. Happy hour is pretty good. $5.50 for a half liter beer and $10 for a full liter. This place is always busy so you'll probably have to stand up. Good drinks though. I will have to try the food next time.
author: James L.

description:
This place is a great place for beers and Eastern European food. It's a casual joint but it also has a certain sophisticated charm to it.

I'd get the pilsner to drink. For food, the goulash was good though lacking any real vegetables in it and it wouldn't have been filling enough if I was really hungry. That said, the price was pretty reasonable.

The only bad thing is they are cash only.
author: Victor W.

description:
In looking at other reviews, I do not get the 1 star reviews.  I love this little hidden gem.  I took a co-worker here today after a disasterous lunch earlier this week at Schroeder's 2.0.  I needed to get that out of my memory.  She loved it, first thing out of her mouth was, the beer is wonderful, the food is delicious and this place reminds me of Europe.  

I had a polish sausage today and a very generous cup of split pea soup.  I find their soup to be on the thin side, but, it was delicious.  I could have added some salt, but forgot it was on the table ro do so.  The polish was cooked with burnt little crispy bits (YUM) and came with mashed spuds, a little kraut and a really good mustard.  I want to know where I can get that, it was good and I love mustards of all kind.  My friend had a bratwurst and declared it delicious.  She had a Czech beer (small) and I had a small Stella Artois.  I rarely drink on my lunch hour, but this was a nice treat and a small enough beer that I felt I could get away with it.  I am a real lightweight.

So, you all keep with your no love for Cafe Prague, I'll keep coming as I am dying to try the goulash next.
author: Donna H.

description:
Cafe Prague is my favorite place in the Financial District for a hearty meal. I studied abroad in Budapest, and ever since I'd been craving the goulash that was my main lunch staple. Cafe Prague is the closest I'll get to reliving my days on the Danube, from the (slow and unsmiling) Eastern European service, to the taste of paprika as I chow down. It's an adorable little restaurant that seems to get more and more crowded every time I go, filled with comfortable furniture that looks nothing like a modern-day American restaurant. 

I've actually noticed an improvement in service over time, but they definitely aren't trying to turn tables around in 30 minutes, so save it for when you can spend 1hr+ on a meal. Don't forget that it is cash only, although they have an ATM in the back if you're in a squeeze.

Tip for ordering - I generally get the normal goulash or szeged goulash (basically goulash with a horseradish thing going - it makes it taste a bit more tart than the normal one), and ALWAYS start with the tomato gnocchi soup. I have yet to figure out what the magical secret ingredient in there is, it might be Czech crack, but it is DELICIOUS.
author: Eve D.

description:
These guys are working on a new menu or a website or something, and that is gonna make me a star because there will be pictures of my food on it. That's right my ACTUAL food, I watched in bemusement, as our exact order was paraded outside and placed on a table while the photographer mused upon the lighting and angles, taking snaps. Once she was done the dish was brought to our table. 
Kind of them. 
Anyhow I put it behind me and ordered another round of drinks. 20 minutes later, no sign of the drinks, nor the waitress, I went and found her. She was playing on her phone behind the bar and reluctantly brought over the bill. At least she didn't charge me for the invisible drinks. 

Appalling service, reasonable food albeit small portions and a good range of beer.
author: Arty V.

description: Terrible customer service coupled with an slimy chicken sandwich resulted in a disappointing first time to Cafe Prague (despite the awesome ambiance).
author: hannah t.

description: Okay food, decent beer but lousy pours (two thirds beer and one third foam), erratic service and cash only. Not a great combination. It was kind of like eating in a youth hostel, until I had to get a hundred bucks out of the ATM to pay for two appetizers, four beers and one goulash.
author: David B T.

description: On a narrow side street in the financial district. We visited late afternoon for happy hour. The happy hour menu isn't really happy hour prices. Moreover they haven't updated their website menu prices so you'll be in for a bit of sticker shock. $11 for a 1L beer and $9 for an appetizer is not my idea of happy hour even in San Fran. The bratwurst app was one nicely grilled sausage with several small slices of crunchy bread, sauer kraut, pickles, mustard and ketchup. It would be a great app for about $4 bucks. Must be all of those import tariffs on the pickles. They offer in-street dining but we opted to sit at the bar... preferring to put a little distance between us and those overflowing garbage bins across the street. The place just has a temporary feel about it as if the landlord is going to raise the rent at any moment and that liter beer is going to become $15. Save your money and go to Prague.
author: Art H.

description: This is not a bad Friday place, and the food is not bad however it's a cash only place in a city where everyone lives and dies by their credit card. I went with a co worker and she had a glass of wine and I had a half pint of beer. She had the Cali vegi sandwich but was constructed like we could have made it at home. Very over priced, I had the steak sandwich which looked awesome but left something to be desired. The meat was good but not very well seasoned. The side salad was the highlight with its very fresh lettuce and veggies, however the garbanzo beans were sprouting. The chairs we sat in were like lawn chairs and not suitable for dinning. The service was pleasant and the beer was good and they were ver liberal on the wine pours. This place is a 3.5 stars but I had to settle with 3 because it's cash only
author: Dominic A.

description:
Looking for a place to get a quick nosh, after haircuts at Brogan and Son around the corner, we had seen a place over on Washington we were going to try, but taking my rotten knees into consideration, Bear suggested we try the closer alley.  Here was a great little wine bar, that unfortunately was closed when we peeked in, (making a mental note to try it later).  Next door - Cafe Prague, which looked kind of funky/chic on the outside, with a kind of makeshift patio in the Euro-street tradition. 

The inside was even more cozy and welcoming, and our waitress/bartender (whose name I HAVE to get next time - homework assignment!) was very accomodating. Guess that wouldn't have been hard to achieve, since it was at the top of "Happy Hour", and we were the only ones there.

We ordered from the HH menu, both of us getting the tomato soup with gnocchi to start.  Bear also got the cheese plate, while I honed in on the spinach salad.  Plus, our hostess gave us free sample bites of tuna on toasted bread bites.  YUM.

The soup was exquisite, not loaded down but gently 'infused' with the gnocchi, which was definitely homemade, not frozen or canned.  My spinach salad was HUUUUGE! It was a bit of a challenge for me to get through, and that isn't something I can usually say about most salads! But this one was generously endowed with EVERYTHING...especially the spinach greens, boiled egg and lardons of crisp bacon. A lemon wedge was provided for extra flavor, but the only thing missing was an extra bit of something - maybe some kind of vinaigrette to give it that extra OOMPH.  I did steal some incredible bleu cheese bits from Bear's plate, and that really helped!

He struggled with the cheese plate, ending up taking some of it 'home'.  That was also an expansive dish, with the four cheeses, (bleu, Cammembert, goat and Brie) served with pitted olives and hot French bread slices.  Wines complemented the meals - Chardonnay for me, merlot for him, as well as some samples of the dark beers they have on tap.

All-in-all, a rather nice 'discovery' in back of Club Quarters.  We will be back to try some of the goulash dishes on the regular menu.
author: Samuel G.

description: This was a really neat find!  Czech and Hungarian food in the FIDI.  I will have to admit that I have not eaten much Czech or Hungarian food, so it is really hard for me to judge the food.  That said, the Goulash Paprika was quite flavorful, with tender bits of meat, a nice gravy and chewy dumplings.  The sauerbraten was also quite nice; however, it had a nutmeg flavor that just did not win me over.  But, again, I am not familiar with this food profile, so it could be amazing to someone else.  The beers were good (beware the huge steins at lunchtime - ask for a small).  The decor was quite casual, with tables and super comfy booths.  Finally, this place is cash only and is not cheap (plates range between $12.00 - $15.00 each; sandwiches may be cheaper).  Nonetheless, I will be back because I enjoyed the restaurant and this place offers something different for lunch.
author: Theresa C.

description: A hidden but nicely placed hole in the wall czech food place that you should totally check out! I got the spinach soup which absolutely amazing and a sandwich.  The service here is quick but the only downside I believe it's cash only. They do have an ATM on site but I wouldn't use it. It's a great place to relax with friends after work tho.
author: Vanessa S.

description: I popped in for a quick cup of tomato and gnocchi soup. The flavor was fine, although clearly microwaved, with the gnocchi still stone cold in the center. Since I was the first customer of the evening it demonstrates a certain lack of attention to details and freshness in to kitchen. The wait staff were friendly and efficient and the decor charming, so the restaurant has that going for it.
author: D W.

description:
Since I rarely get a lunch break while at work, I never have the opportunity to dine at any of the countless restaurants in the Financial District that are only open Mon-Fri till about 3 or 4pm.  So i miss out on some of these hidden gems like Cafe Prague.  But since I was off last Fri, my boyfriend asked me to meet him for lunch since he had his daughter later that evening.  I wanted to go to Mixed Greens since he always raves about their salads, but I guess he's sick of that place, since that's where he normally eats nearly everyday.

I have to say, I felt like I was in Europe, the moment I stepped into the restaurant.  The vintage, out-dated and unpretentious decor, was border-line tasteless, and yet it was extremely inviting; charmingly comfortable.  And at first I dis-liked the loud techno-house type music (which I only like at night club), but then it changed to Diana Krall-type romantic music which I love.  

The menu was gigantic with countless items under salads and sandwiches... it took me awhile to decide.  My boyfriend ordered one of their native beers, but i just had a diet coke since I had to drive up to Atherton after our lunch.  Well if I didn't have an appointment, I most likely would have given a 5 star rating, meaning if you are not in a rush and can take at least a 2hr lunch, then this cafe is outstanding for lunch.  Unfortunately the only negative about this place, is that the wait for the food is extremely long.  Otherwise, the food is absolutely delicious!  I enjoyed every bite... we shared our sandwiches and the tomatoe soup.... yummmmm!
  
Will definitely come back when I have nothing but lunch to worry about:)
author: Myra M.

description:
Me and my Czech partner liked Cafe Prague. We have lived in Praha together and after relocating to San Francisco, our expectations regarding the quality Czech food available were greatly exceeded when we dined at Cafe Prague. The food we had was authentic Czech cuisine, the tomato and gnocchi soup was what Babička would have made back in Czech, the steak tartar was an authentic Czech dish, the mulled wine was nice, and as always the Czech beer is A+++
Looking forward to our next dine in at Cafe Prague. Thanks team for your service and for providing this dining option :)
author: Shaun M.

description:
I love the ambiance. Perfect for a late weeknight beer. I enjoy the outside seating as well as the decor. 

I have only tried a few dishes and they were rich, but very good.
author: Frances M.

description:
Come here for the beer or to drink - the environment and menu is most useful for happy hour on a Friday; food is pretty expensive and slow in coming.

The staff is very hands-off which works if you're super aggressive in flagging waitstaff or only need to order beer or have time to kill.

I came around 6 pm on a Friday (apparently, happy hour ends at 7 pm and prices go up on sandwiches and other dishes) and ordered a tomato soup. The food is decent and well priced for the area (Financial District). My friend was late in coming to meet me, and we weren't able to get our orders in after waiting around 20 minutes.

We left for a show at Punchline after to eat lunch at the club.

Cafe Prague is an average experience; I'd come to drink if invited, but would prefer to frequent Hidden Vine next door even if I had to pay a few more bucks.
author: Jen B.

description: Very poor experience. Bad wine selection; and worst of all not a single sign in the whole restaurant that will tell you it is - CASH ONLY! Food was average. CASH ONLY - what a joke.
author: V C.

description:
What is the Czech word for "clueless?"  We ordered 7 sandwiches-- 6 of them came back wrong.  OK, I get it...hold this, swap that-- you're gonna miss some. But 6 out of 7?  How do you *do* that? 

I got something that wouldn't need substitutions-- and they added something that wasn't even in the description.  

Would have given them one star, but the split pea soup was pretty good.  And it didn't have mustard all over it.
author: J C.

description: So they don't take credit cards but they do serve straight up delish Czech fare.  Dumplings that are legit and a goulash worth writing home about.  I like the fact it is tucked in an alleyway-a hidden jewel.
author: Bobb S.

description:
I really like this place. Great sandwiches and soups (live their lentil). Its a little pricey, but everything is down in FiDi. the happy hour is stellar with lots of good beer and nice apps! Tucked away in an ugly alley, its still a happening spot!.

CASH ONLY (only poo poo)
author: Mimi D.

description:
My colleague and I walked down the alley (Merchant Street) on our way to the Hidden Vine wine bar. Unfortunately, but now understandably, they were busy and had no available seating. We decided to try the Cafe Prague next door, which had plenty of room.

Cafe Prague's wine selection is almost non-existent. They had just one red wine by the bottle, which was something fairly unpleasant from San Louis Obispo. Their food selection is OK and was completely adequate for light snacks. You wouldn't go out of your way for the food, but we had no complaints about it. 

So far, this was all somewhat to be expected. After all, it's called the Cafe Prague, so they're featuring beers rather than wine, and the food basically went along with that motif. It was a little loud, with people standing outside smoking cigarettes, the smoke wafting in the open doorway. I should add that this doesn't bother me in the slightest, and even adds to that old world Eastern European ambience. But, I know some people would find it annoying.

The bill was $61.85+tip, for a beer, a bottle of wine, and 3 appetizers--not an unreasonable sum for downtown San Francisco.

The completely unacceptable shock came when I laid down my credit card and was informed that they took cash only. There is no signage to that effect and, more importantly in 2015, there is no reason for it, other than to be abusive to customers and, maybe, to hide cash under the table. There are numerous options (like Square) that make it easy for even the smallest merchants to accept all major credit cards for a flat 2.75%. If this place can't afford that as a cost of doing business their business model doesn't seem sustainable. I happen to carry cash, so they couldn't rope me into using their on premises ATM (hidden in the back) which presumably exacts a usurious additional fee.

If they were extraordinarily good at something, perhaps I would just deal with this insult and patronize them anyway, ala Peter Luger's in Brooklyn. Given that Cafe Prague isn't especially good at anything and would only warrant a 3/5 rating even if they took credit cards, I certainly won't be going back.
author: Mark F.

description:
This is a great little gem tucked away in the financial district. The food is delicious with a wide variety of heavy middle European classics to lighter fare in the salad department. 

I ordered a particular beer that they happen to be out of that day and the server immediately recommended something comparable; I was very happy with her recommendation. 

The outside seating doesn't have the best view but it has a slower paced feeling that allows you to wind down during the lunch rush. To that effect, the service was a bit too slow for a business lunch hour. 

I will go back for the ambiance and chill feel.
author: Ellen B.

description:
I just don't get this place or why people like it. I had a better time there than I did at the now defunct Mission St location but only because I was there with a fun group of people. 

Here's the review of my last Cafe Prague experience: http://www.yelp.com/biz/cafe-prague-san-francisco-4#hrid:q6du4vvKRav9yFd1VGKg8w/src:self

This time I rolled in with my friend to a meetup event at about 6:40 giving us 20 minutes to take advantage of the happy hour deals.  Five dollars for a half-liter and eight for a full liter are OK prices, not great. 

The beer selection is sparse and remembering the half and half trick with the two Czech beers from last time I ordered it again. I was given a liter mug that was about 4/5ths full http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=jy_RGAeAvNeCv5BxZsUWFA and a bill for $10.95, Ten dollars for the beer and .95 cents tax. I pointed out the listing on the happy hour menu that stated liters were $8 and he said that didn't include half and half. I looked at him incredulously and he told me to talk to the owner. I told her I was willing to pay the listed price for the beer, ignoring that the mug wasn't nearly full, and she agreed. After 7 the beer price goes up to a ridiculous $7 a half-liter so I only had the one.

One of my friends ordered the Polish sausage appetizer and it took 90 minutes for him to get it and then he was short changed when he paid.

These people either have no idea what they are doing or they are purposely trying to chisel people, either way Cafe Prague is on my no-go list.
author: Manny F.

description:
I pick this restaurant with my friend for dinner. We order pork with dumplings, cabbage and beer. Food had no flavor at all. Price for two dinner and beer was almost 60$ and they take cash only!!
This restaurant is just over priced.
author: Tereza S.

description: Delicious food and thoughtful service. We especially loved the caprese salad, Italian meatball and Bratwurst appetizers.
author: C D.

description:
I yelped late night dining and came up with what I was hopeful would be a gem since most yelpers have been very helpful for me.

Well this was a disappointment. Mainly for the lousy food quality.

The place itself is quite cool and inviting. Outdoor seating and tables, very European/Czech feel to it so that's very cool. The artwork was eclectic and interesting giving the place a bit of a bohemian feel. Service was decent but then again, the place wasn't crowded so this comment may not be reliable.

Now to the food. Hmmmm. I ordered the duck and it was a large portion which made me a little worried since larger bird means older bird, maybe not as tender and I was right! It was dry and tough. The dumplings were bland and seemed to swell up in my stomach making me feel a bit uncomfortable later. Cabbage was good so at least something edible. Oh and the Pilsner Urquelle was great. I guess as long as you have a keg of it and serve it at the right temp, we're good to go!

Two star since they were open late as we were served around 1230am.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
Nice place, pretty good food, interesting beers, lousy service.  Each visit has been worse.  Today:

1 minute wait to be seated.  Nice.

15 minute wait before asking someone to take our order.

3 minute wait until someone does.

20 minute wait until 2/3rds of the order comes out.

12 minute wait until I ask them to cancel my order as I have to get back to work.

2 minutes later they bring half my order to go, offer a brief apology, and say it's on the house.  Apology accepted, but I won't come back.
author: Dave H.

description: Really good food, I came here with friends on a Saturday night because we'd planned to go next door to the hidden vine, but we wanted some more substantial food first. It was about 830 at night and we were one of maybe 3 groups there. The server was very nice and attentive. The menu had a starred note thay the pork loin was their most traditional item, so I figured why not? The pork was tender and flavorful with a hint of rye seeds. It was served with cabbage and dumplings (that were delicious). The total for 3 people was only 50 bucks which I think is more than fair for the city, the only real complaint I have for this place is that it's cash only. I had to run down the street to an atm because I never carry more than a 20 really. But other than that, definitely recommend and will go back again.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Cash only!  Receipt doesn't have their name on it, so a tough place to take the team 

Nice room, on a fun alley in the financial district, good selection of Czech beers.  Nice waitress. We had appetizers:  Good brats, meat balls, the tuna on toast, were all very good. 

We had a great time. 

Recommended
author: steve P.

description:
Great place ... good Czech beer, decent food ... 
One star for living in 18th century or so ... Restaurant which doesn't accept CREDIT CARDS? Are you kidding me? Hello, it's 2015!!!
author: A B.

description:
First of all, I want to say that the food is good, and they have some traditional Czech meals. The service is OK, not horrible, but not outstanding.
HOWEVER (you knew that was coming)...

It's rather EXPENSIVE, and they are CASH ONLY. This is not posted anywhere, I looked for it after I got the bill....the only place you will find this info is at the register or from the waitress. They do have an ATM that charges you $2.50 per transaction, plus your bank fee. So, for a simple dinner and beer, I had to withdraw $120. Ouch.

Also, the MUSIC IS HORRENDOUS!  If I wanted to have dinner at a high school prom, I would be a teacher/chaperone....
Seriously, the music is extremely loud, day or night (I've been a few times for lunch) and they play super poppy trash.  Its really a major turn off.
Lastly, why don't they have Krusovice anymore? It was by far the best beer they had. 

Will I be back? Despite the fact its the ONLY restaurant in California I've found that serves Knedliki like my grandma made....probably not.
I just can't take the abuse anymore. I'll made my own knedliki instead.
author: Jessica T.

description: The food menu has a lot of surprises (on the upside) and the general feel is a real tucked away gem. Authentic Czech staff, great beers, frosted mugs.
author: Matt T.

description: I visited this place on my lunch and I love it! I ordered sausage with mash potato, plus soup for total only 13$ Food is amazing, I felt like my mom cooked for me! taste as homemade work! Recommended to visit this place at least to try if you from Easter Europe!
author: Alex B.

description: I rather enjoyed Cafe Prague. The food was good and unique for me. Not something I eat very often. Beer was good and ample, service was good enough. Definitely worth a revisit.
author: Jim S.

description:
I grabbed lunch with a friend at the bar, tried a lunch dish and some dessert.

What I can generally say is that I like the theme of the restaurant - I don't know many Eastern European eateries. I even like the small alleyway on which it is situated - sort of like in a real Eastern European city. What I think is missing is just an element of more.

More Czech beers - is it difficult to get Budvar? Perhaps it's not possible, but I am sure more can be had than things like Urquell and Spaten (isn't Spaten German?).

I thought the desserts particularly disappointing - NY cheesecake, and chocolate lava cake. Why have these? What about some middle European dessert? Or even Viennese style tortes?  I guess on the whole, I would like to see a little more imagination in the menu, and perhaps bit more theme consistent with Prague name. It doesn't all have to be Czech ... the Republic used to belong to the Austro-Hungarian empire, so anything middle Europe would work well.
author: David K.

description: Our group had 12 people, and they only had 1 waitress at the time, so we tried to be patient. It was a very bad experience however. The waitress was smoking hot but extremely lousy. We sat there for 20-30min without water while she was standing at the bar browsing pictures with another customer. When the food came out, our stew were cold, yes, cold. The beer was weird too; my friend was ok with it, but I found it was not cool enough.
author: K T.

description:
Nice little Euro-Tavern in an alley.  They have a couple Czech beers on tap and a couple of tasty goulashes on the menu (I prefer the one with kraut in it, but they're both very good). For me the real winner here is their soup and sandwich lunch - possibly the best in the FiDi for the $$. The people working here seem to put in a good effort to keep their customers taken care of, you might have to flag a cute, young Czech gal down to get your bill but that is a minor issue... The seating can take some getting used to if you wind up along the wall on a sort of padded bench seat with lots of big pillows.

The place can get full, very full, and there are small tables outside which can help but you'll have sporadic service. After work there is a good happy hour which makes those large steins a reasonable bargain, especially for this part of town.

BE AWARE THIS IS A CASH BUSINESS, no credit cards accepted although there is an ATM inside.
author: Jay A.

description: We had an excellent, comforting late supper after a nearby movie:  authentic goulash paprikash with Czech style dumplings and a big bowl of French lentil soup, beer and wine.  Prices are fair.  Cash only was no problem for us.  Comfortable cafe seating plus a silent big screen with sports. The apple streudel was tasty and very apple-y and cinnamon-y--just different from streudel I've had in Budapest and Vienna.  We'll return.
author: nancy s.

description: Great food and service.  The server as we sat down, informed us right away they only accept cash, but have an ATM right outside.  Decor is fun just like back home in Slovakia.   You have to see it to understand.
author: Ron G.

description:
I thought it was just me but noticed several people complained about the music being over the top loud. Went with a couple friend to relax and it's like a restaurant impersonating a nightclub. 

We had a party of five. The food took a long time, maybe they were short staffed on Saturday? My husband also received an appetizer instead of the meal he ordered.

The food was just okay but to end more positively, the decor was really interesting!
author: Tina J.

description:
Came here 2 days ago for lunch.  I ordered fresh orange juice and goulash paprika with tomato soup with gnocchi.

The good.  Tomato soup with gnocchi was great, especially the gnocchi!

The bad.  My orange juice came out looking like it was freshly squeezed, but one taste and it was obviously made with rotten oranges.  I could taste that the oranges used were fermented.  Next is my goulash paprika.  It was very bland, with no kick at all from the paprika.  Also, bits of the meat were actually cold.  I didn't think much of it since the meat definitely looked cooked, but it's been 2 days and I'm suffering from my worst case of food poisoning.

My husband ordered szeged goulash and his dish was also very bland.

We won't be going back again.
author: Gemma ..

description: Had a tuna melt and tomato soup for lunch.  Nice place with cushy seating, a few tvs, some music.  Like the atmosphere.  Soup was a little on the sweet side.  I enjoyed it more after balances with some pepper.  Great construction on the sandwich and good tuna quality.  Lot of interesting menu options and price is reasonable.
author: Marc S.

description:
Came here a while back when I was on vacation.  We picked the place originally because of its convenience to our hotel and because it was still open, but I think I picked a winner.  

The great things about this place were: 
1) huge beers (win!)
2) good, home-cooked and hearty tasting food
3) authentic atmosphere (my dining partner lived in eastern europe before so I trust his judgement on this one)

The only unfortunate thing was that there was basically no one else there.. but it's deep in the financial district on a weekend night.. what can ya do, I guess.  The people working there were nice and did not rush us to leave even after the closing time so that we could finish our beers.  It's cool little spots like this that make me jealous of all the people that live in the city.. 'Czech' this place out!  omg.. sorry for the pun.. ouch.
author: Jeanie C.

description:
Dinner and drinks one Sunday night watching the game - virtually empty restaurant in FiDi. This is one of those confusing cash only places that still exist, so stop at an ATM on your way! 

Beer is good, cheap, and plenty. 

Food is... alright. The meatballs are one dimensional. Tomato soup was pretty good. Friend got a traditional Czech dish, and he couldn't decide if it was bad or if he just didn't appreciate Czech food. Cheese plate was pretty good. 

Service isn't exceptionally warm or quick, but it's certainly not too bad. 

All in all - great for drinks and maybe some appetizers, but not for dinner.
author: Andrea B.

description:
had a great lunch - out the door for ~$18 with a beer, sandwich, and a nice sized bowl of soup.  All three of us thoroughly enjoyed the meals and will definitely be coming back.  

I wasn't a fan of the music, but different strokes for different folks.
author: seth g.

description:
It's a small place with a nice decor.  The happy hour prices seemed decent enough and there was good Czech beer.

There was only one server working there, when I went there were only 2 other people there so the service wasn't bad.  However, if there's a big crowd, I imagine the service wouldn't be that great.

The dinner menu was pretty limited with about 5 entree's at around $15 each.  With entrees being $15 each, you would think they would take credit cards, but they don't, so if you're planning on eating here then make sure to bring a lot of cash.
author: Dipesh G.

description: My friend suggested this place for a weekday dinner and I was quite impressed! The tomato soup is really, really delicious - the cup size is huge so I would recommend getting that to start out with. I ordered the pork chop with dumplings and had enough for leftovers. The portions are large enough and can even be shared family-style.
author: Katarina D.

description: We briefly stopped by on our visit to San Francisco. We had a nice time, good beer, friendly service. They had a live music and place had a good atmosphere. My gf is excited for our trip to Prague now.
author: Stewie A.

description:
It's baaaaack~

I'm happy to have stumbled upon this on Yelp. I loved their charming set up in the Jackson Square Historic District. But inevitably times + places change, so what can you do?

This incarnation has a bit of the old and new. Some of the old Euro decor + music, a smattering of dining tables + couches, alongside a new flat screen TV....We tried not to get sucked into the latest headline on the tube. We both felt that it would add to the ambiance if they showed one of those travelogue or classic B&W films instead.

It was the perfect day for one of their soup + sandwich combos.  I was too hungry to study their menu and instinctively went for my favorite tomato soup with dumpling + tuna melt. The tomato soup has a nice warm-the-soul aura, and sandwich ~ a great blend of tuna, capers, mayo and fresh leafy greens hugged by two lightly toasted slices of dreamy focaccia. Heaven indeed.

PS: Happy Hour 4p-7p. Cash only. Czech food + beers available.
author: Cathy K.

description: Great bar, cool regulars, tasty split pea soup and massive Czech beers.  Love the hidden away feel in the financial district.  Service is great and the outdoor patio is really nice.
author: Michael S.

description:
Great tasting soup and sandwich for under $10 in SF ... the place has ambiance, and you can actually talk and hear each other:)

Love the mural, couches, service, price ... actually found a lunch place that I can eat alone and doesn't feel awkward.  

I'm hesitating to share this hidden treasure - cause I want to be selfish! :)  Enjoy!

It is cash only, I'm sure they are working on it!
author: A T.

description: I really enjoyed this small hole in the wall restaurant. It's a small menu of really good food. Cash only is the only bar to the 5th star for me.
author: Kyle W.

description: Abysmal service. We only saw our waitress two times over the course of 1.5 hours. Finally had to ask her to bring the bill and it took another 15 minutes before I just went to the bar and paid. Also, didn't like the outdoor "tables" which are basically a piece of plywood suspended between two saw horses. Much better options nearby including the wine bar next door.
author: Z E.

description:
within a minute of walking in the door, an owner asked me if I was or spoke Czech.  Though I don't, it made me feel at home.  Respectable eastern European beer selection, fun crowd, not too crowded or loud, some live music sometimes top 40s.

The feel is transporting.  Something about the furniture and the people and the decor makes it feel like you took a one night trip to Prague.

I hear they have tasty lunches, too.
author: Lauren J.

description: Just went back and got the steak sandwich with split pea soup--definitely one of the best things on their menu.
author: C L.

description:
Serious disappointment on my last visit. It had been a couple months since I visited here for lunch and a couple of incidents have made me change my mind about this place.

I sat at the bar as normal and ordered up a sandwich with soup. I noticed that the staff had changed. No familiar faces this time. But what i observed was disturbing. Food safety.

I watched as a man cleared a table and returned dirty dishes to the counter behind the bar. Then he began a frantic search. I saw him look around, look under the bar and on shelves. It turns out he was looking for a soup bowl for another patron. They were out of clean dishes I guess. So what did he do?

He grabs a dirty bowl from the dishes he had returned. He walks to the sink in plain view for me sitting across from him. He turns on the faucet, rinses the dish with one hand (no soap, no scrubbing mind you) and proceeds to re-fill it with soup and then walks it out to a new customer.

I was stunned at such behavior. But the deal was sealed on my last bite of my sandwich when I pulled a 6 inch blonde hair from my sandwich. NASTY....I won't be back!
author: Krusty C.

description:
I love this place, the food is delicious (especially the brastwurts) and the waiters are very welcoming and nice. 

Although, the music can be a little too loud sometimes.
author: Joyce C.

description:
After walking around Chinatown all day and looking at the jars at the Chinese herb stores, everything on the menu here looked pretty appetizing. There were a couple of unfortunate things that kept this place from getting more stars.
