First, the music. Now, I'm no music expert, but I'm pretty darn sure whoever was singing "Hotel California" at the top of the lungs in Spanish is NOT a big star in the Czech Republic.

Second, the menu. There were, basically, five items on the menu that could be considered Czech, or have origins in the area. The rest were kind of American. I can see American items on the menu, but if you're a Czech restaurant, well, please have more Czech things.

I was fearful of trying some of the items because they sounds like they might be, well, large, and I didn't want to tote a belly full of roast duck up some damn 45 degree street for seven blocks. So I opted for the safe sausage and mashed potatoes.

It was perfect for me. I was looking for something light (as in quantity) and it was a tasty sausage with some sauerkraut and pickles and mustard and a nice dollop of mashed potatoes. The coffee was Euro-style, which is to say, "full flavored," which is to say, why waste time drinking six cups when you can do it all at once? I liked it a lot. Some nice beers on tap. We left with our hunger quenched but not nappy. Service was good, but we had to have her count the change again because she messed up. Handled it well though.

Not that I'll be hiking around the Financial district any time soon, but I would really like to see some more Czech items. My fault for not asking how large the portion was on the duck, or the dumplings, or the other items. And for God's sake get rid of that music.

I would come here again to try the other items, though.
author: Wayne D.

description:
Hankering for some grilled bratwurst and authentic sauerkraut?

Craving a liter of Czech beer for $8?

Jonesing to watch the Tour de France on a big screen?

Aching to hear Ace of Base's discography played in its entirety?

Look no further. 

Tucked away on Merchant Street, deep in the Financial District, this place is a true gem.
author: Kathleen L.

description:
I had a thoroughly "meh" experience at this place. 

Although Cafe Prague is fairly accessible by muni, it still took me a while to find. It's sort of tucked into an alley-way...but that's mostly a side point.

I'm half Czech, so I've had a lot of Czech food over my lifetime and this place was nothing to write home about.

Between me and my fiance, we had:
"czech fries" to start (fries with raw garlic on them. They were pretty tasty but not really czech. We followed that up with Gulash and Svickova. The gulash, a meat stew with dumplings, had waaaaaaaay too much paprika in it. The svickova, a sauce made of pureed root vegetables, served with dumplings and beef, was also mediocre. It was a bit too runny and definitely lacked flavor. Overall, I would give the food a two. 

For desert we each had a strudel (an apple based dessert). Now, that the restaurant got right. It was fantastic and a great way to end the night. 5 stars.

As for other elements, the atmosphere was pleasant and non-stuffy. There was a good mix of Czech and American patrons. The waitress was friendly, and there was a pretty big TV one could watch. The noise level was also quite low (which I appreciate).

The one thing that stood out was that they didn't take debit/credit. Although there was an ATM on site, it was broken. So, I suggest you bring some mullah with you.
author: Tereza M.

description: Delicious Sauerbraten lunch yesterday! Good Czech beer, nice ambience, service was good too.
author: Elise Y.

description: My lunch companions and I stopped in at 11:30 for a quick bite. Nearly an hour later, after my friends had finished their lunches, mine was still nowhere to be seen. They are very short handed at lunchtime and despite how good the food appears, it really doesn't deserve to show at the top of the ratings.
author: Wendy C.

description: Came to Cafe Prague 10 years ago with my Czech wife and she loved it.  I thought growing up in California, food is OK.  10 years later, certain Czech cuisines I appreciate.  So my wife and I after 10 years decided to check out this place again after all this time and to our surprise, a BIG DISAPPOINTMENT!  Per my wife, food was blah and had no flavor.  We had Svickova and Gulas.  The food was expensive and definitely not worth the price not to mention the meat they used is very tough (use tenderizer maybe?).  Oh by the way, this place is all cash only too.  I guess they need to make sure people pay before they can contest the crap food with the credit card company! ;-)
author: Irel Q.

description:
We were visiting from out of state and have a special interest in Czech food.. so, we found Cafe Prague in a Google search. 
We didn't expect upscale or fancy atmosphere which was fine. 
But, there were some glaringly poor aspects which, unfortunately, were not outweighed by the good food.  
We both enjoyed our food, it was well presented and nicely put together. 
The meat in my companion's meal was, however, a lesser cut of meat with gristly bits throughout. The sauce and dumplings and beer were excellent though.  

The decor of the place is eclectic and cozy and comfortable. 
The thing that really ruined the otherwise charming atmosphere was the overly loud and obnoxious (yelling and brash) music which didn't fit the place at all!  We do love many types of music but this was just totally out of place and WAY too loud. 
If we had not been looking specifically for a Czech restaurant, we would have gone elsewhere.

We asked the waitress if it could be turned down... she did turn it down but a barely detectable amount.  We engaged her in conversation about the music and asked if she had perhaps a different type she could put on. She got defensive and angry and said if she changed it to what we wanted, then someone else would complain and it was just not a good idea to change it.  Then she said ok... you tell me what to put on and I'll put that on.  We suggested something more in keeping with the restaurant... maybe some European style background music.  She grumped off and changed it to some very nice french cafe type music.  She came back to the table to ask if that was ok.. we said YES! much better! and a fellow at a nearby table chimed in and agreed wholeheartedly.  There were very few people in the restaurant that evening.

We continued our meal and ordered dessert, when she delivered the strudel to our table she commented...  we'll see if you find something wrong with this too.
Perhaps she meant it as a joke... but, it came across as poor attitude. 

The strudel, by the way, was excellent!  and a generous portion.

The owner was not present that night and we can't help but wonder if things would have been different if the owner was there. 
We strongly suggest he talk with his waitress regarding how to treat customers and the restaurant's music.  Although we had asked for an out of the ordinary adjustment, we were very polite and (we felt) reasonable in our request to turn the music down.

For those looking for Czech food in SF - a small cafe called Paprika is well worth the trip. Friendly owners and superb food. And... no, we are not in any way affiliated with them nor the owners.
author: K B.

description: Good, but not outstanding. Very little "Czech" food, at least during happy hour - but I'm not really sure if that's what they're going for anyway. It's Cafe Prague, not Cafe Czech Republic I guess? I had the split pea soup. Again, good but not outstanding. Nice place to go for some good beers and a light meal if you happen to be in the neighborhood. Service was fair. Everything is presented very cute. Seems clean, too.
author: Celeste H.

description: Great service and unique Czec dishes that were not just run of the mill. Our wait staff was hip and fun. Located in a little alley the overall experience was nice.
author: Sam B.

description: Great outdoor area, good food and beer selection, awesome "hidden" street location....knocking off a star for the annoying pricing system - a beer is like 4.55 or something so you get a handful of change back all the time.
author: Edward Y.

description: It's a big space, pretty chill, has some outdoor seating in the alleyway where Transamerica Pyramid looms overhead.  The interior is like a time warp, with lots of carpeting and upholstery.  The large beer is a much better deal than a small beer.  The sausages are good but the sauerkraut was dry, according to my sauerkraut connoisseur friends.  Only downfall is that it is cash only, but there is an ATM machine in the hallway.
author: Mirba E.

description:
This was definitely a good experience. It is cash only so as long as you don't mind, it's fine. It's somewhat hidden away in that it isn't on any of the main streets. I think that added to the atmosphere though.

I came here during one of the Giants v Royals games (game 3 of the World Series, I think) so it was pretty loud, though not by much. My friend and I could definitely carry on a conversation without needing to raise our voices. It definitely wasn't as packed as some other places that night and I got the feeling that the folks that were in that night were regulars anyways.

The food itself was excellent. I ordered the NY Steak sandwich and had the Split Pea soup to go along with it. Both were delicious.

The downside to this was that after finishing our meal, it took a half-hour to get the check for some reason, and we'd asked several times. The place wasn't too packed and half the time, the waitress was on her phone. We ended up going to the counter to pay - I'm almost wondering if this was what we were supposed to do all along anyways, but we did see other tables getting their checks as they finished so I'm not sure what was going on.

In any case, the food and atmosphere was great and the service was (mostly) good and I would definitely come back again.
author: E E.

description: On a business trip to SF this was a good place to duck into for a pint.  A decent size crowd on a weeknight was a good sign so I sampled several of the giant brews with a few friendly regulars.  Bartenders that were quick with a pour and made for a great night.
author: J G.

description:
The decor of this place is lovely and we really liked the atmosphere. 
I was a little disappointed that they were out of my favorite dish-- the Fried Cheese. 
My Paprika Goulash meat was little overcooked. 
The duck was very good, but there was little of it. 
Menu selection is rather sparse. 
Service was great!
author: Andrej K.

description:
Dear Yelp 
Get yer facts straight -  this place is neither German or Polish.
Their own web site describes them as Chech or Slovak.So unless you want to be called Canadian please change it.

Their menu seems OK but lack of knedlichki call for some punishment.How one can run Chech place without them?!

Beer selection is good although prices are crazy and service at the time of my visit was poor.
author: Dupa B.

description:
Love the Krusovice. The place is a little empty but it was a great introduction to Czech beers. $6 a beer. 

Didn't try the food.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I never got to go to the last location. I always wanted to, it kind of reminded me of Kan Zaman. The reds and all. And then it closed and I was like "&&%" but I had a second change recently.

A gentleman took me out to lunch to Cafe Prague. What was good about this is that he's Czech and well, so it was safe I was gonna eat good food. He asked me whether I wanted to eat traditional or not. 

You see, all this European divisions don't go very well with my history. In fact, I probably learned about Europe history in college. Czechslovakia, Poland, but then they fought and so it was Czech Republic and Slovakia then Serbia, or something that sounds like it...does that even exist...what? The Nazis and who? I barely know US history, how am I supposed to remember some history from some other continent. I hate history.

Anyway, so some people call gnocci dumplings. So anyway, if you get dumplins....


Oh, what the hell am I saying. It's basically German food, with the cabbage and all, but 1 liter beers. 

The duck was super good. it was the best duck I've ever had. Never mind these plastic looking ducks hanging from Chinese restaurant windows. Those are gross, this duck was tasty! Who knew duck could taste so good after all that mud it eats.

Trivia: Czech guy told me that the guy on the photo with the owners was the Czech president when he visited San Francisco.

The beer, get the beer.
author: Alexia R.

description:
I love Cafe Prague....I definitely don't go enough. I used to go to their mission location but it closed so now I go here. Everyone I take here loves it! The goulash is amazing and the dumplings are so fantastic we always order extra. I read some of the other reviews and can't believe some people don't like this place. It's definitely a more laid back environment but that doesn't bother me. And I don't mind waiting for good food...but really don't remember the service ever being bad or the wait being too long..it's a great place to go with friends for conversation and beers. If you like sauerkraut, pork, dumplings and yummy creamy sauce try the goulash. There's two of them I prefer the one w/ sauerkraut but they are both excellent.


So so good ! !
author: Deborah H.

description:
I swore to myself when I started this review, I won't make any Check/Czech puns. No "Czech it out". Not a single "asked for the Czech". No. Because I'm classy. 

It's a little hole in the wall. Off to the side. Hard to find, almost. You end up going around the Transamerica, just past the people protesting scientology and the yuppies filtering through north beach who wanted to avoid the Chinatown Crawl. 

There, you meet with a man with an eyepatch, who buys you some exotic, dark beer and tells you of his plans to bring down "the system". You ask him, precisely, what "system". He winks at you with his one eye. You say, no, let's not be coy, the only other people around are the serving folk and the half-dead people slumped over a half-empty, frosty mug. 

He tells you to shut up and passes you an envelope. The envelope is full of blueprints drawn in crayon and lots of suggestive violent phrases about "unexpected demolitions". 

Stuff like that. 

Me, I got a quesadilla and a couple of beers and sat around and shot the shit, because I'm like that. Revolutionary praxis and that sorta shit's for the subversive. I just want beer and food that seems...curiously out of place. 

Further visits will warrant further exposition, no doubt. No doubt.
author: Daniel V.

description:
Cafe Prague is a lovely, out-of-the-way place. The decor is charming. The beer is tasty. The food is good ... when you get it.

I had the steak sandwich with the tomato soup. I'm not good at describing food. The sandwich was the right size for lunch. The soup was good.

My girlfriend had the soup and some pork dish. I don't remember what it was because by the time her food came, I was done with my food. She asked the waitress to wrap it up to go since we were running late. That took another 15 minutes.

Reading the other reviews, forgetting orders is one of the features of the place. If you can deal with that, it's a great place to eat.

Note: this is a cash-only place.
author: Philip B.

description:
I feel a little sorry for the place. It is in an alley and they try so hard with their signs to get business. You go into the place and it actually looks like a Cafe but with beer flowing through instead of coffee. Nice large TV for games and comfortable seating all around to chat, study or dine. When I went I was the only one there and it was literally a one-man show by the bartender. He sat me at the bar, took my order and cooked the food. 

Portions are pretty good but the quality is mediocre at best. I got the steak tartar and my only expectations was to not get food poisoning. The meat was mushy and tasted like ground tuna in relish and ketchup but it was decent on the garlic toast. I also ordered a dumpling dish which lacked salt but was very unique and hearty. They open late and is seldom busy so a convenient spot to hang.
author: Ed L.

description:
great spot in a quite alley in the middle of barbary coast (near pyramid tower)
good sandwich with a different yet savory spinach soup. And the huge pitcher of chec beer was delicious. Nice spot
author: Raffi A.

description: Went here with a small seminar group tonight.  Had a very tasty quesadilla off their HH menu.  Two huge star killers:  waitress wasn't very attentive (perhaps a smiling a bit more would have helped) AND WTH with no credit cards?!  For a place like this, I didn't expect it to be cash only.  Thank fully, my team members covered me!
author: Guillermo S.

description:
Hooray for Cafe Prague!

I used to come here when I worked across the street at the Transamerica Center on Sansome, and recently came back to attempt to impress a couple of Europeans. It's one of the best authentic Euro-based places I know of, and the only Czech one in the city (tips appreciated if they are more. Have to honor the Czech in me). The bartenders are native Europeans and there is a warm, friendly feel inside. The beer is good and the decor makes this little alley-side cafe cozy.

One of the other great parts about Cafe Prague is that it's an easy cab or bus ride home... they feature a great happy hour, where I've consumed too much wine and cheese for my own good. It's right on the 10, 12, and 1 lines... as well as along busy Sansome and California Street. I specifically thought of this place when I avoided Happy Hour in Austin due to the fact I had to concur the "Mo-packed" freeway to get home. Nothing like SF city happy hour convenience!
author: Kristin F.

description:
I walked by the new Cafe Prague a few times before it opened and I didn't realize it was the same one on Pacific Street which I hadn't been to in years.  I went there for lunch today and ordered a tuna sandwich to go with the tomato soup and everything was really good.  The interior is still new and a little bare but they tried to bring the look and feel back.  The staff was friendly and I got my food in a very short time.

It's been getting some good press recently but I hope that the location down an alley with no cross traffic doesn't doom it.  They did put out signs on the street and there were a good amount of people in there so it looks to be doing fine so far.
author: Blake B.

description: Really enjoyed the food and laid back atmosphere of this restaurant.  Our waiter was very attentive and helpful answering any questions we had on the menu.  I had the paprika goulash which was tender and spiced just right.  My husband had the pork and dumplings which came with red cabbage.  I'm German and this is some of the best red cabbage I have ever tasted.  The pork was tasty as well.  The nice selection of European beers and a cozy atmosphere.  I felt like I was in Prague.  The prices are reasonable...just be aware that it is cash only.  They do have an ATM if you need it.  I'm going back and hoping to try the duck which unfortunate they ran out of tonight.
author: Audrey M.

description: We went for dinner.. Mistake. No one else was eating and we soon found out why. The entrees arrived WITH the appetizer and were stone cold. They took them back and re-did them, which made the pacing reasonable. We both had goulash, but different types. Both were unremarkable, rather boring and the meat used had a huge amount of gristle. With all the great places to eat a 5 min walk from this place, you should avail yourself of other opportunities. On the plus side - they didnt screw up the beer order. smirk
author: Will G.

description: I came here for lunch a second time and really enjoyed the food. The atmosphere and service were very nice too!
author: Tina P.

description: Terrific salads! Happy hour prices on the food until 7pm. Would return.
author: Eliza D.

description:
Now when someone asks me what kind of food I like, I can include "Czech food" as one of them.

The cash-only aspect seemed off-putting at first, but they have an ATM inside so it's not a big deal at all. The atmosphere and scenery of the place was exotic yet comfortable at the same time...it actually felt like I was in Europe. A beautiful place with very comfortable seating.

We ordered the polish sausage appetizer and the szeged goulash, both of which had a unique taste that was amazing. The goulash was quite different from the Hungarian goulash most people are familiar with, and it comes with these doughy dumplings that you can use to absorb the delicious sauce. All the food has a very fresh, home-made and authentic taste to it...it's as if it's made by people who actually care about what they're doing and know how to do it, not just some sweatshop cooking staff that grabs pre-cooked stuff from the hot plates, pours corn syrup sauces out of packets and puts too much salt on everything.

Oh, and there's also the awesome Czech beer which comes at prices that are pretty good for a restaurant. I got a 0.5 liter glass of the Spaten and finished it way sooner than I thought I would.

Overall, I'd recommend this nice little place to anyone who has cash and wants to try something different.
author: Noah F.

description: Its a pretty nice place with good atmosphere.  Unfortunately, they don't take credit card, which comes as an unpleasant and rather expensive surprise.
author: Brock B.

description:
This is a funky place.  I happen to be of Czech heritage (and speak the language) so I had to visit Cafe Prague to take in the culture.  I drank the Czech beer (which is incredibly good)  and chatted (mostly in English but occasionally in Czech) with guys from Poland, Slovakia and the Czech Republic.  It was great!  

I had to try the pork loin, sauerkraut and bread dumplings, which we had every Sunday when I was a child in the 1940s.  The quality of this dish was mediocre as the meat was tough.  This is the Czech national dish but is also big in Bavaria.  The dishes I had in Munich were tastier.  As others have mentioned, the service was slow.  I had to ask three times to get a second beer.  When the bill finally came I was charged for four beers!  (Apparently they charge by the number of times you ask for a beer rather than the amount you drink - LOL). That go straightened out and the bill went down by $11.  

Overall, if I did not have this personal affiliation with Central Europe I would not bother returning.  But I will be back, if only for the beer and the camaraderie!  And maybe I'll try the goulash next time.
author: Robert B.

description: Visited for lunch to try some European cuisine. They had some signature items to select from. I got gylash and dumplings and my friend got pork and cabbage. My dish was lukewarm and pretty bland. My friend was struggling with pork chops that seem to be pretty tough to cut through. I've had people recommending the duck dish but I cannot remember if it was available for lunch.
author: Skate K.

description: The monthly meeting place of SF's 3D meetup. Great fries, good beer, horrible ventilation. You'll leave smelling like cooking grease.
author: John M.

description: Three friends and I came here for a late lunch at 1pm today, and the place was far from busy, which is why I was surprised at how poor the service was. The time between when the first and last person got their food was about 10 minutes, and the server did the "shout out" method of delivery ("who had the X?") for every single dish and each drink (I waitressed for many years -- remembering who had what is part of the job). Most annoyingly, my iced tea and water glasses sat empty for the entire meal until I asked for a refill. Aside from the service, the food was unremarkable and veg options were extremely limited. The only thing that rescues it from a one-star rating is that we were seated immediately without a reservation, and I liked the atmosphere (the outdoor tables are particularly nice on a sunny day).
author: Gaelen X.

description: Found this place through a referral from a local in our SF office.  Fantastic spinach salad and split pea soup.  Service was prompt and friendly.  Bring cash since they don't take credit cards.
author: Dirk W.

description: weekday afternoon, was wondering European Pilsner and some food w lady company. the menu's got two types of czech beer and one from munich. the food selection poor, not that they don't have enough dish on the menu, but besides polish susage, theres nothing echte eastern Eastern European. im not being a smartass, im from that part of the world originally. spent 15-20 min at our table fighting flys then fave up on the place. the only original here is the server's russian accent.
author: Norbert H.

description: Fantastic! Went here for the first time with the gals and really enjoyed it. Food was served pretty quickly and was so yummy! Totally tucked away in an alley, and never would have noticed if not for a friend's recommendation. Will be back for sure
author: Jen C.

description:
Pros: Cozy, casual decor and you can usually get a table there on Friday night.  Czech beer, Czech music, Czech attitude.

Cons: The staff are rude and slow, the food is expensive and not great (though the appy plates are dinner portions).  The big screen tv dominates if you're looking in that direction.  They play cheesy Czech versions of old movie theme songs and Christmas music out of season, sometimes way too loud.  The owner is an ***hole.  They only have four kinds of beer so you better like lager.

Their old place had more ambiance but this one has more space and is more bar than restaurant.  Come for a few Krusovice, then go find food elsewhere.
author: Simon B.

description:
This is a cozy little hangout on a small street right next to the Transamerica Tower.  The seating is a little funky - not really a problem, just a little funky. Along one wall there is a cushioned bench that is terribly lower than the chair on the other side - but I like benches in cafés so its ok. There's a huge round table that seats like 8 people.

I didn't try the food, but people around me seemed to enjoy.

I hung out there for an hour before and an hour after a friend arrived. Between us we had two Americanos and a lemon soda water. $6.57 - that's a good deal in the middle of downtown in a quiet place. 

Big plus for outlet for laptop. I'll go back when I find myself in the area again with an hour to kill.
author: J T.

description: visited again on a weekday this month. Duck dish was great as always, and the bacon bean soup was very good too. Our waitress was nice and attentive to us, but then again, I purposely went when it was already pass busy lunch hr so I could get fast service and full attention.
author: Paiyu G.

description:
If they had turned down the music just a bit...

If the service was just a bit better at the beginning...

If they had not used a credit card folder to present the bill (cash only)...

If the place didn't smell like something was burning...

I'd probably be awarding four stars. The food was really good. Loved the veggie sandwich with chicken added, generous amounts of everything, and complemented by a choice of soup or salad. Really dug my chicken and oat concoction.

Friends were not returning to work and had beer. They were massive.

But as I stated at the beginning, our menus were thrown down in front of us when we arrived (subsequent waitresses were much better), the music kept being turned up after we asked them to turn it down (it was very loud), the credit card folder was misleading, and there was a constant smell of something burning. That might have been my friend's sandwich, which was slightly burned on the ends. He might have yelped fewer stars.
author: Jason B.

description: Service was basic, but the food was fantastic and the feel of this place makes me feel as if I have returned to Europe.  Make sure you have cash.  Very homey filling food.  The spinach soup was great.
author: April M.

description: Had lunch at this little café tucked away in an alley. The décor is very European and the wait staff were pleasant. I had the lentil soup, which was hot and had lots of vegetables. it was a bit on the watery side and lacking many lentils, but the flavor was good.  It comes in a large portion considering it's a side with the main course (sandwich in my case).  I had the melted brie over turkey and prosciutto and really enjoyed the crusty baguette and fresh greens.  The goulash my dining partner had looked good and the polish sausage at the next table made me drool (just a little).
author: Eve C.

description: I am always on the lookout for a good Czech restaurant, which can be difficult to find in California. I was initially disappointed when I saw the menu as there was no svickova listed as I had seen on a menu posted on a website.  I asked the waitress if the sauerbraten on the menu was actually svickova and she assured me that it was.  I can understand that sauerbraten is easier for most Americans to understand, but what you are getting is the superior Czech dish, not the German one.  This meal was fantastic.  A true joy.  Better than the svickova my mother used to make.  It was served with the traditional dumplings (knedlicky) and a little cream and cranberry along with a slice of lemon.  Accompanied with some Staropramen (Old Spring) from the Smichov neighborhood of Prague, you have the real deal in Czech cuisine.  Finished the meal with an apple strudel and coffee.  I only wish that I lived closer to San Francisco.
author: John S.

description:
I tasted the goulash my coworker ordered and loved it! I wish i ordered it instead of the tuna melt.  But then the tuna melt was so good too!

Sandwich came w/ a side salad which is around $9.  

One thing was that we didn't know it was cash only either.  They should really have a sign somewhere that says that.  As well, it took way too long for the food to come. I don't know what the deal was, server or cook?  And when we asked for the check, it took over 10 mins to get it to us.   Service does seem to be lacking a bit.  Def. coming back to eat the goulash next time!
author: AhLin C.

description: Good beer. Nice view sitting outside. Food was somewhat mediocre. The sausage was just some stuff you would buy at Costco. Harldy authentic. Service was fairly good.
author: Ddc C.

description:
I never made it out to their old location but always thought it looked cute, so definitely wanted to stop in to try out their happy hour.  Location is convenient, on a low-traffic street/alley mid-way between the Financial District and North Beach.  A few tables with chairs and umbrellas outside for drinking al fresco on a warmish day.

Got inside and the space was much larger than I thought, kind of open and industrial feeling but with warm colored textiles and artwork around.  Large tables look good for groups, but we sat on cushions along the wall at a table for four.  Our server came over right away and we ordered czech beer at the happy hour price.  Nice place to sit and chat, and after a while one of the servers brought over a gratis treat, not sure what it was called, but was basically small squares of pizza speared with toothpicks - a tasty little nibble and a nice surprise.  

Didn't order any food but a table near us had the cheese plate and it looked pretty solid.  Overall a cute place!
author: Jaimie M.

description:
let me premise this by saying that i am a mostly vegetarian (occasional fish) and do not have experience with czech food, nor would i eat most of it, since it's meaty.

that being said, when you go for the ambiance and happy hour menu, this is a great place! the green salad is amazingly fresh and good, and is a good size for the price. the garlic fries and cheese plate are tasty as well.

they have beer and wine happy hour specials and those are all decent. i like how cozy this place is, and the random music selection that usually goes something like: bon jovi -- madonna remix -- journey -- led zeppelin -- c&c music factory. etc.
author: Kate W.

description: My favorite place for lunch on a week day.  Sandwiches are served with soup or salad.  Food is very tasty and reasonably priced.  Beer selection is great.  Deserts and coffee are the best.  So they have it all.
author: Irina T.

description: Took a walk, just looking around and found this interesting place with Staropramen & Urquell on tap. Interesting snacks and goulash with dumplings. Feels like I'm back in Prague or maybe Bratislava. Plus they have fencing on tv. Odd choices of music, but again I remember a odd club in Prague with house/hiphop. I could really have stayed here all night and felt comfortable. The staff was excellent. The prices were good. The crowd was definitely enjoying themselves. It was not overbearing and the bar was constantly changing so there were routinely available seats. I will definitely be back. It's a shame there aren't more places like this around.
author: Eli S.

description: Good looking girls working there , good  music, and I lovet the dark Krusovice beer...
author: Peter D.

description: Very cozy place with a nice atmosphere......but a horrible service which I would normally expect in Soviet Bloc countries being myself from there. I waited for over 30 minutes to get the only dish I ordered, not a single time did the waitress come up and apologize. Another customer had to literally grab her and show her that that I am waiting for my order but am being ignored. Again, no apologies, no smiling but a rude " it is coming....." To the management I would suggest to remind his staff that they are in US where good service is appreciated and well remunerated.
author: svetlana f.

description: Most of the main dishes are served doused with a bland, under-salted sauce, and with chewy, tasteless dumplings. Even if you force-feed him a boatload of Krusovice Pilsner beer first, Brillat-Savarin would still turn in his grave.
author: David L.

description: We found this place by accident - it's at the back door of the Club Quarters Hotel where we were staying. My wife is Serbian descent, so she got excited about the chicken paprikash. We ordered beer - limited choice, but they had what we wanted, so it didn't matter. The waitress decided to bring us a huge plate of meatballs that was really good. (despite the posting date, this was March 2011)
author: Bill F.

description:
...technically this should be an update.  However, seeing that Yelp, in their infinite wisdom, decided to make a whole new listing for Café Prague, i am forced to write a new review.  Aha! I shall buck the system and make this a quasi-update instead by putting my old review on the bottom.  

Technically, to justify Yelp's new designation, they have moved locations.

However, it is the exact same place as old (see infra) with some minor differences that make a world of difference...to me at least.  So as of now...two stars but it may be bumped up (see infra).

First, the space retained very little of the other location's charm...total bummer.

Second, and man this is such the deal breaker too, the new location is sorely lacking in counter girls that are basically Sylvia Saint look-a-likes.  I used to go out of my way in the mornings for a coffee from Café Prague to chat it up with some fresh off the boat 20 something ridiculously hot Czech, Polish, or Hungarian girl that liked my accent.  Now...sadly sadly sadly sadly (I can't say sadly enough) lacking...however, I am willing to pop in on occasion just in case!  I will report back!


********************************************

3 star rating
11/10/2007

Consistently inconsistent.

I gave it a shot.  Actually about thirty shots give or take.  And while I waited for the place to just click it just doesn't go smoothly.

Don't get me wrong I love this place but you just never know what is going to happen on each and every visit.

Prices changes daily it seems.  Sometimes even between the time you see the price on the outside board to when you pay.  Coffee orders are usually 75% correct.  ATM machine is always a crapshoot.  Ice some days...some days no.

If you are like me (an eastern europeanphile) you'll just chalk it up to the culture from which it sprung.   The interior is laden with Prague images and artwork.  They play Czech music often (which may be a minus for most).  The servers are aloofly nice.  The food is downright good but a little pricey.

All in all...I still recommend this place.  I'll just have to whittle my visits to just a beer on the patio only times.  Otherwise, I just can't count on getting the same experience twice...and unfortunately, this is right by my work and my mind is on other things and I need a little more consistency to make the rest of my day easier.
author: Chris D.

description:
They've returned in a new location in an alley with the tasty big Czech beers and the funny Czech music.  Didn't have the food, but will likely try soon.
Read a negative review about the decor and that feels kind of petty to me.
The place is a bit weird with odd sized tables and couches and the service is kind of how I'd expect, slow.  Order food if you want to.  Order a beer or two if you want to.  Sure, they're not hovering around you, but whatever, it's a laid back place.  
Big Czech beers.  In a big, big mug.  Go up and get one.
author: Kev M.

description: This is a good place for a sandwich and a beer.  They really decked out the place to remind you of Prague.
author: Byron L.

description: Gadda love a cool pilsner and a hearty sausage on a nice summer day in SF!
author: Yan L.

description: Cute hidden cafe in one of those alleys you probably walked by but never really noticed (like me). The murals are beautiful and the whole place has a "Czech" feel to it. They have some comfy couches and a large round table, which seated our large party perfectly. Only came here for a drink so can't comment on the food. They only have a few beers on tap but they have Czechvar and Krusovice. Great low key and chill place to have a drink.
author: Linda C.

description:
I'd only been to Cafe Prague for drinks after work, but one weekend, I took some friends here for breakfast.  

I know it's supposed to be Czech, but should the service be?  It took us about 15 minutes to get the menus.  Finally, the waiter sleepily brought over the menus.  Did I mention we were one of only 2 parties there?  We studied the menus, and placed our orders.  Bagels?  Oh, no, we're out of bagels.  Oh, that? We're out of that.  Oh, this?  We're out of this.  Finally, we asked what they did have.  Not much was the answer.  We ordered what they did have.  Oh, they were out of that, too, and told us when our food came (what did come). 

What the hell, people!
author: Pete G.

description: great eastern euro food.  best goulash and soups.  I love unique beers and they have a great selection.   if you wanna escape to europe for a meal this is it!!! go
author: Troy C.

description: Cafe Prague definitely exceeded my expectations.  When you think of food from Eastern Europe you tend to thing of soup and unleavened bread but the place was great.  Very friendly staff and the food was amazing.  I had the Lox on Foccacia and wasn't expecting much but the sandwich was loaded with amazingly cured salmon, cream cheese, capers, and thinly sliced onions.  A perfect balance for my palette but I know everyone is different.  When I go back, I am definitely trying the goulash.  There are two options on the menu.  My coworker had the spicier one which looked awesome.  Very traditional but you can see that they do a good job keeping the authenticity of the Czech cuisine.  The restaurant is a bit hidden but well worth the search.
author: Steve H.

description: I had not had goulash since a visitor from Hungary cooked some up for my family a few years ago.  I had the non-paprika spiced version and it was great.  I was asking for more sourdough bread to sop up the sauce.  My lunch companion had the steak salad, which appeared to me to be a much larger version of the mixed green salad that came with my entree, only hers had generous amounts of thinly sliced, medium rare cooked steak on top.  I also had a cup of the lentil soup, which was good but could have been spiced up a bit for my taste.  The beer selection is limited but Spaten brown was just fine with me although I would like them to offer something smaller from the tap than 500ml glass since I did have to go back to work this afternoon.  A 375ml sized draft beer option would have been good.  I will definitely be back.
author: Russell W.

description: Have been coming to Cafe Prague a lot lately. It is a great place for lunch. Salads are wonderful and large. Happy hours are really fun. You can enjoy a Sharks game while chugging down great cold liter of Staropramen with excellent appetizers such as a tartar or a sausage. Will not break your bank either. Everything is reasonably priced.
author: Alex k.

description:
While at Bruno's on the corner of Ellis & Fillmore, my GF and I were sitting to some pints of IPA while waiting for an old rugby teammate of mine.  Our waitress was a nice Czech woman who recommended this place.

After going to the Mission, we discovered, Cafe Prague has moved! It is now downtown in the financial district.  After trekking to the other side of SF, we were not disappointed.

The menu selection is limited, but delicious.  They specialize in a few dishes and make them extremely well.  I had the Paprika Goulash and a huge glass of Czech beer.  The Goulash is NOT how grandma used to make.  The meat was tender and the sauce had a great tomato/paprika flavor that warmed your insides.  Washing it down with some light beer, and dark for that matter, made the experience perfect.  

This is more of a lounge spot rather than an eatery in my opinion.  If want to try something new, and have great beverages served, check it out.
author: Jayson F.

description: I love the fact that they have $8 Bavarian sized glasses during happy hour (these are $13 at Schroeders) and that they have both the light and dark Krusovice (the dark is currently my new favorite beer).  The appetizers are $7 so my friend and I decided to get a bratwurst which wasn't all that great.  They were playing random 80's music the whole time which reminded me of movies where everyone in Eastern Europe is just figuring out about American Music/TV from the 80's.  I would like to give this place 4 stars but frankly I would not come back here for the food.  Happy Hour beers, yes, food, no.
author: Scott G.

description:
Previously, I had reviewed this place and gave 5 stars due to the polish sausages, the beer, and the atmosphere.  Great casual place for beer and sausages.

Now, I've discovered they also have delicious sandwiches and salads!  Very impressed!  This is one of my favorite places to go for lunch during the work week. 

Thanks to Andrej K's review, I just learned that they also have fried cheese?  Need to try that next!  Thanks, Andrej K!
author: Avid E.

description: It's really 3.5 stars.  The ambiance is pretty, and the service is fast.  The duck and red cabbage was decent.  The sausage was also decent.
author: Niniane W.

description: Their nicoise salad is very hearty and and worth a try. The ambience is pretty relaxed and on weekdays not too loud or busy. There is a tv showing sports, but it's not so loud that it dominates.
author: Anna J.

description: The food was very good.  The service was fast and the prices were very reasonable.
author: Robert W.

description:
I can't say that i like their food. (had a sandwich and soup)
Also personally "cash only" is not very convenient 
but, oh boy, czech beer is my favorite!!!
try dark or light draft krusovice.... 

happy hour is also seems like a great deal. 
3.50 from 4pm - 7PM.
author: DImitry G.

description:
If you are a fan of Czech beer, then this is the place to go.  Pricing of their beer at happy hour is good.  They've even put half and half officially on the happy hour menu now.  The $7 bratwurst appetizer is fantastic.
Bartenders and waiters are all from Czech, and lots of Czech frequent this place so you know it's authentic.
My friend and I tried their tomato and split pea soups, our vote is to go with the split pea bacon soup.  Delicious.
Goulash paprika is good and paprika added a kick to the dish, and i finished all the dumplings on my plate.   
They put the Giants game on which kept us there for probably an hour longer than we would otherwise stayed, if you like good beer and a neat place to watch some sports game.  There is cafe Prague at your service.
author: Cynthia C.

description: Sweet unique place. I just wish they took credit cards. The split pea with ham/bacon soup is wonderful. I just wish it was BIGGER. The food and the staff and the ambiance...all thumbs up. I love this place. so unique and cozy. Love it.
author: George K.

description: Terrible, terrible service. We ordered beef tartare four times. I'm not kidding. Four (4) orders. It never arrived. We did receive several complimentary appetizers, toasted bread/tomato stuff/cheese blahness. It took arm-waving to get beer. Oh, and they didn't have any change -- at a cash-only establishment. Sigh.
author: Mark W.

description:
what an adorably cute place! honestly, i did feel like i was back in prague with the decor and food.

we stopped in for happy hour and ordered two caesar salads, the cheese plate, a cup of hot mulled wine, and the apple streudel. the salads were huge - crispy crunchy croutons and good dressing. 

i think the belle of the ball  was the cheese plate though. huge gigantic servings of blue cheese, brie, goat cheese, parmesean, greek olives, cucumbers, tomatoes, and fresh french bread. it was so good that we couldn't finish all the cheese (cheese coma).

dinner was topped off the with warm apple streudel which was amazing with the bit of whipped cream added to it, too.

and the hot mulled wine was the icing on the cake for a chilly january day.
also - cash only!
author: laura f.

description:
Just opened at their new location on 3/18/09. It is just down the street from work so we decided to try it. For previous reviews look here...     

yelp.com/biz/cafe-prague-san-francisco

The tomato soup was fantastic. Sandwich toasting machine was a bit ambitious. Each of our lunches was a bit burnt and the interior became smokey at times. We called it authentic. 

Location in a grungy alley must keep their rent down; but its a good thing - nothin on the lunch menu is more than $10. We'll be back.
author: J. W.

description:
Cafe Prague has Krusovice on tap. Both light and dark lagers, they have both major version of Krusovice on tap. Given that Krusovice is one of the most wonderful beers ever created, this means Cafe Prague must be one of the most wonderful cafes ever created.

Of course, Cafe Prague is not one of the most wonderful cafes ever created. BUT, I will hand it to them that they are playing into a niche market - Czech Stuff - that has been severely under-served, not just in SF, but in all of America. You can come here, and drink Czech beer, eat Czech food, listen to Czech music, attempt to speak Czech, and interact with real Czechs themselves, all at the same time. So, A+ for providing me that opportunity.

The only reason this place isn't 5 stars is because...having tried some of it...I don't really actually like Czech food!

Still, they have Krusovice on tap. One of two places to ever do so in California, and one of only a handful in all of America to serve this most awesome of beers this way. I will be back many, many times.
author: Tolga E.

description: Tomato soup is good, and chicken sandwich was pretty standard but did not disappoint.
author: Michael E.

description: This is a cool, off the beaten path spot. The beers they have here are like German liter size. And the beer rocks. What did surprise me was the food- damn good for lunch and happy hour.
author: Jim B.

description: just ok place with their mediocore meatballs, poor selection of beer.
author: Lyra S.

description: tomatoe soup deli, good bear. With so many food trucks now on the financial dist area and their offering becoming an expensive one,  this Cafe is a good value meal. Love the sandwiches, and the atmosphere there, i never feel in a hurry.
author: Rafael G.

description:
first time having Czech food. i liked it, but i wouldn't say i loved it.

the place was half full on a Tuesday night, we could choose to sit outside which i usually love, but it was a bit cold.

we ordered a split pea soup, and the pork chop with dumplings.

apparently the chef accidentally made 2 soups, so the waitress offered us another one for free :) that was very nice of her.

the pork chop has good flavors, not too dry, but the cut is not my fav. And a bit problem was as soon as we got the plate, my bf noticed a long hair in the dish :(

overall it was not bad, but not overly impressive either
author: Danielle A.

description: I love the sorta hidden location.  The food can be good and it can be average, but it's pretty much always alright.
author: Henry A.

description: excellent svíčková na smetaně (Marinated Beef Sirloin) :)
author: Ivan R.

description: This is a great little neighborhood find.  The ambiance is fun, the service good, the beer selection even better and their bratwurst are divine.  I didn't have high hopes when I first walked in, but I left with a belly full of good food and drink, so I have no complaints!
author: Jessica H.

description:
One time I had a late dinner here with my brother before my movie.  Very cute place tucked in a FiDi alley way. Christmas lights still hangs in the front. The décor inside is homely in a good way. Stuff looks like they were collected from garage sales with pictures that hint the restaurant's Czech pride. My brother and I were very excited, as we both never had Czech food before. I had the szeged goulash with dumplings and a Czech beer. Granted I never had Czech food before, but I thought the $15+ for meat and bread was a little too much. Worse, the waiter was kind of a jerk. He was very apathetic in serving us. He seemed to care more to chat it up in the back of the restaurant than making us feel welcome. In the end, we ended up spending $50+ just on two dishes and two beers. Unfortunately, the place did not accept credit cards. Cash only. First off, I didn't see a sign saying cash only. And second, how can you not accept credit cards when you overprice your dishes. 

If you need a nice cute spot to maybe grab a beer and have an intimate conversation with someone, then Café Prague can fit the bill. However, it's best to grab dinner elsewhere.
author: Peter T.

description:
This is apparently the second branch of this restaurant, the other being around Van Ness.  The old Cafe was in North Beach and the food was about the same then as it is now:  nothing to write home about.  Did not rate even near food I had in the real Prague.  I had the Goulash and was sort of disappointed.  Good thing was they had Czech beer on tap, but I would have hoped they would have had more than just the standard Urquell, Czechvar and Krusovice.  

Open only at night, this branch seems to be a gathering place for East Europeans. The worst part is that they don't take payment cards, which always makes me suspicious, let alone cause a major inconvenience.  I will probably not be returning until they do.
author: David E.

description: I went for the first time a few weeks ago and am happy to say that I enjoyed it very much.  It is run by Czech people and I could almost imagine that I was actually in the Czech Republic.  The beers we served by the half-liter or Liter.  My 3 other friends and I had the Steak Tartar (Tatarak) and the chesse platter.  We all got the traditional Gulash for our entrees.  While it was delicious, if you have ever been to the Czech Republic and had it there, nothing else compares to that.  I had 3 Liters and then was way too full to have anymore.  The staff was very friendly and we felt very welcome there.  I will be going again soon.
author: Ian P.

description: Good spot for a weekday lunch except service can sometimes be slow.  They have vegan/vegetarian options (lentil soup & green salad) which are good.  The salad has a lot of ingredients.
author: K V.

description: I dropped in for a Kruovice Dark, which came in its own branded mug that weighed the same as a bowling ball. Not really. Good stuff though, cool off-the-beaten-path location (okay, sort of). Will try their food next time.
author: Maximillian M.

description: We came in  at happy hour and it  was dead, which is fine, but I would think the bartender would be able to more attentive than he was considering that the place was DEAD.  He just seemed annoyed.   There was nothing at all inviting or friendly about the place and so we didn't stay to eat.  Maybe the place is better when there are happy people around.
author: Jorah N.

description: A few weeks back I went in here on a cold weekday for lunch, got the sandwich with lentil soup and a nice, dark Krusovice and it was perfect. So tasty, nice atmosphere. Friendly and helpful staff. Big wide bar and comfy stools with plenty of space to enjoy your platter and down a few hearty brews.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: This place is probably more of a 3 star but I do enjoy the beer and their friendly service. I have been here twice now and I really like the KRUOVICE beer. Seriously i have no clue how to pronounce it but it tastes pretty darn good. They have a good happy hour that lasts till 7pm with beers only being $3.50. The food is pretty substandard though. We tried the quesadilla and it was pretty week. If you need to eat, go with with the cheese plate, it is a much better value.
author: Jeff P.

description: Good food. Decent prices.  Looked like good beer (I was with my boss, wasn't going to drink at lunch).  The atmosphere leaves something to be desired, as do the waitresses, who were frankly a bit rude.  At least the food was good.
author: Adam T.

description: I am amazed this place has so many stars. I was excited first as I love the city of Prague, my most favorite place in the world, but the place sucks. The worst wine and the worst food in the city. My friends organize a lot of meet-ups in this place and I usually avoid everything but bear.
author: Liza A.

description:
Just went here for lunch and the place is amazing.  Great food and beers, solid atmosphere and music and the staff is incredible.

"Krusovice, it's more delicious than...Budweiser"
-Hot Czech Waitress
author: Jay T.

description: This cute little place is right across the street from my office, and we hadn't noticed until today. We went over for post-work-vent-about-layoffs-happy-hour- it was decent. For happy hour, wine was $2 off, which was nice. We had three glasses of pinot each and the cheese plate. It was a nice simple place with a cool Eastern European decor. Service was decent, they seemed a wee-bit short-staffed, but it wasn't too busy, so it was fine. I'd go back again, but honestly, I prefer happy hours with cocktails, not just wine and beer.
author: Ieesha C.

description: I really enjoyed the beer and the goulash. It was my first time having this eastern European standard. The waitress was extremely nice and friendly.
author: John G.

description: theyre back in business!! ...well kinda...just opened up a few days ago at this new location!!
author: Kaylan S.

description: this place is pretty chill.  i'm not a huge fan of german or czech beer, but the ambiance is good, staff friendly, and an overall good time.
author: Tomas M.

description: I love Cafe Prague.  Great Happy Hours and the beer is cold and served in gargantuan steins!  The owners have become friends and make me feel welcome every time I come in.  And I love the chow...their lunches are remarkable especially considering the size of their tiny kitchen.  Give em a whirl...
author: Larry E.

description: I'm kinda surprised to see this place get such good reviews.  I went in the middle of the day last week for coffee and a snack with my friend.  The decor is cute and it was cool to hear people speaking Czech, but the waiters acted like we were interrupting them and were kinda pissy about us not spending a lot (about $15-16)--even though we were the only customers!
author: Chris R.

description:
i went to Cafe Prague today for lunch with a friend of mine around noon. the place was fairly empty when we got there, but filled up quickly.
the new space is nice, though feels less like a cafe and more like a restaurant. all of the seating is a little different - chairs, couches, etc. - so come early to get your choice.

we both ordered soup and a sandwich. i had the tuna melt with chicken soup and she ordered the turkey with tomato soup.
the food was fresh and the soup served in cute bowls. my tuna melt was good, but the soup was a little bland and begged to have more "stuff". my friend's was happy with her sandwich and the soup is the one she always gets, so she loves it. it was tasty.
being a beer whore, i also tried a mug of the Krusovice dark beer everyone is talking about (they have dark & light). it was served in a serious looking glass stein, not a regular, wimpy pint glass. the beer itself has an interesting flavor, unlike any beer i've tasted before. though it reminded me of barley tea, if you've ever tasted that ... but of course in a beer format. $3.50 for a mug during happy hour would be a steal ! too bad that it's not closer to my place.

service was good, very good even, considering there was only one woman on the floor. she was very nice and very Eastern european (a good thing). i will definitely come back to try other goodies on the menu.
author: FrOg SoU P.

description: Great atmosphere.  The sauerbraten was terrific.  The goulash was just OK.  They do not take credit cards, so beware.  Cash only.
author: Chris R.

description: I checked this place out at their 4-7 happy hour yesterday.  $3.50-$4.00 beers that were delicious.  The Aussie bartender is really cool and easy to talk to.  I will definitely be going back for lunch and happy hours.
author: Daniel M.

description: Great, albeit smallish (it's a cafe, what do you want) selection of beer. food is just decent, nothing to rave about there, but the ambience is great and service is super friendly.
author: Paul B.

description: Much better ambiance than their location in the Mission. Cute restaurant/bar that truly has a Czech feel to it. I have been to Prague before and feels like a true cafe in Prague. Good food, good beer and for sure better service than in the real Prague. Nice waitresses and bar tenders. Great place to go and relax.
author: julie q.

description: So, my husband and I just moved to SF and were excited to visit Cafe Prague as he was born in Prague and I have spent enough time there to love the food and beer. It is tucked away in a little ally and when we walked in were greeted by blaring 90's cheesy techno beats and and disco ball spinning at full speed likely capable of inducing epileptic seizures. The bartenders/owner was visibly drinking behind the bar and, against the wishes of almost every patron within the bar, kept turning the music up to the point where my ears were ringing. At least they had Krusovice on tap, which I have not been able to find outside of the Czech Republic. The first beer I ordered was definitely Krusovice and I ordered a second, however I was brought something completely different despite their insistance that it was. I love Czech beers and know them very well at this point...it wasn't an effing Krusovice. One of the other patrons then offered up his own ipod, which they played for a few songs, but then switched back to the 90's techno, at which point my husband and I left. It was an incredibly weird and awkward experience and definitely not worth going back. Can some other bar in SF please carry Krusovice on tap???
author: Sheena S.

description: Pretty good for the authentic "knedli" and such.   Owners are very nice as well.  Sitting at the counter is very nice.
author: Ryan E.

description: yeah!! They are back the place is great!!!! Come over to check it out at merchant st.424 btw. sansome st.  n battery st.
author: josh w.
